Dear Bob
Thank you for your recent letter about National Health Regulation 29aaa, Statutory Rules 1989 No. 292.

I can assure you that guaranteed renewable policies written before 1 December 1989 are not affected by the regulation. A guaranteed renewable policy is generally regarded as one which includes a condition allowing the insured the right of renewal on payment of the appropriate premium. Benefits may be subject to variations in accordance with a formula specified in the policy; in this way the liability or potential change in liability is assumed at the time the policy was initially effected.

The question of whether or not non-guaranteed renewable accident and sickness insurance policies written before 1 December 1989, which relate benefit payments to periods of hospitalisation, continue until expiry is primarily one for decision by the insurance underwriter. I understand that these type of policies may be varied or revoked at the option of the insurer and therefore it would be open to the insurer to substitute the basis for payment of benefits from periods of hospitalisation to, for example, periods of disability or incapacity as certified by a medical practitioner. In this way, the insured's entitlements would not be degraded. From the Government's viewpoint, however, there is no question but that non-guaranteed renewable policies may continue until expiry date.

In any event, I would be surprised if there were in fact very many accident and sickness insurance policies that were not guaranteed renewable, since such policies would be of little longer term value to the subscriber. I enclose for your information brief summaries of a number of policies, all of which provide for guaranteed renewability.

The effect of Regulation 29aaa is to exclude insurance policies from the definition of ``accident and sickness insurance business'' which relate payment of benefits to hospitalisation periods. This means that the intention of the legislation, whereby only registered health benefits organisations may conduct health insurance business as defined and then only within a community rated environment, is clear. The making of regulations excluding certain kinds of business from the definition of ``accident and sickness insurance business'' is expressly provided for in paragraph 67 (4) (b) and Regulation 29aaa fits squarely within that provision.

In our view, the period of two months advance notice of the regulation was sufficient to allow insurers to consider variations to existing and consequently future policies. The regulation should not result in any loss of business or gap in insurers' livelihood, but this would obviously depend on the ability of individual insurers to respond in a timely manner. Moreover, removal of the ability to limit accident and sickness insurance benefits to days in hospital, when accident and sickness invariably does not begin or end at the hospital door, could well lead to the development of policies more closely aligned to their stated intentions.

The Department does not have details of either the number of policies or persons covered and such information is not available through the office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. However, the number of policies or persons covered is not the real issue.

On your last query, it was not considered that amendment of section 67 of the National Health Act 1953 would be appropriate, since the regulation making mechanism to exclude certain types of insurance business from the definition of ``accident and sickness insurance business'' was provided for in paragraph 67 (4) (b). I cannot agree that Regulation 29aaa is of the same character as the 3 kinds of statutory instruments whose purpose would be more appropriately covered by legislation which would amend, in this case, the National Health Act.
Yours sincerely
Neal Blewett

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY: PROPOSED MOVE TO JERVIS BAY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and everybody else. When the Prime Minister was torpedoing Mr Beazley over the proposed move of the Royal Australian Navy to Jervis Bay did he say that the environmental impact statement (EIS) had itself thrown up `a number of serious environmental impacts in relation to the proposal'? Is it not a fact that chapter 19 of the study done by Sinclair, Knight and Partners Pty Ltd-that is, the environmental impact study-says that there could be some possible environmental impacts but studies of these impacts are not conclusive and they could be reduced by safeguards; that they do not warrant abandonment of the project; that there is no basis at this stage for rejecting the proposal in principle; and that it recommends further studies as a final decision does not need to be made for several years? Can the Minister say how the Prime Minister came to mislead the Australian people by misrepresentating what was in the EIS? Was it deliberate or by accident? Will the Minister now release the draft EIS in its entirety so that the extent of the Prime Minister's deception can be revealed, or does he intend officially to delete or censor chapter 19 and confine his selective handing out of this and other relevant documents only to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, not to the Parliament or the people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not take down every detail of that question but I hope I can do it justice. Firstly, I do not intend to censor anything and that is certainly not the intention of anyone in the Government. I do not have section 19 of the Sinclair, Knight draft with me, so I cannot confirm that it says exactly what the honourable senator says, but I will take his word for it and assume that it does. It has never been the case that what is wrong with this EIS, and indeed what was wrong with the proposal to move the whole fleet to Jervis Bay, is necessarily what is in the draft EIS. A part of our concern is with what is not in it. If one goes back to the expression of concerns that my Department gave to the Department of Defence on this issue, it related to the fact that a whole host of items were simply not adequately covered in the draft, or were not covered at all. We were very concerned about that. I pointed out some months ago that I thought there were grave difficulties with this EIS, and because my Department has pointed that out over time it should not have come as any great shock that the Prime Minister announced the decision he did the other day.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the draft EIS is concerned, and its publication, I indicated in the Senate last week that the Government would be looking again at its terms of reference because we are proceeding with an environmental impact study into the move of the armaments depot and whether or not it should take place. So it is a matter of looking at what the terms will be. Certainly there will be publication of something. I cannot undertake to tell the Senate now what document that would be. That would depend on negotiations that I have with Defence. As a general point it ought to be noted that the studies that have already been done in this EIS, particularly the marine studies in Jervis Bay, are significant studies. They certainly will not be wasted. Jervis Bay is one of the most beautiful spots on the coast and I would have thought that all the work done so far can be of use, to both the Commonwealth Government and those who live there, in working out the best way to protect the area in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government learnt with sadness at the weekend of the death of Dr Andrei Sakharov. Dr Sakharov's name is synonymous with the global struggle for human rights. As well as being an established academician and a recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, he was a man who spent his life trying to right wrongs as the conscience of his people. He gave up a life of privilege and official acclaim in order to confront injustice, a sacrifice which he accepted with courage and humility. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has sent a letter to Dr Sakharov's widow extending sincere condolences on behalf of the Parliament and the Australian people. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of Senator Gareth Evans's letter to Dr Sakharov's widow.

ANSWER.PARA: It was with deep sadness that I learned of the death of your husband, Andrei Dmitrovich Sakharov. I know that the Australian Parliament and people join with me in extending to you sincere condolences.

When we look back on the life of Andrei Dmitrovich Sakharov we remember many things about him. In his chosen field he became one of the world's most distinguished physicists. In the field his conscience chose for him, his name was synonymous with the global struggle for human rights. And in the role the people chose him for, he emerged as a parliamentary leader.
We remember Andrei Dmitrovich Sakharov as an academician, as a recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, and as a simple human being who saw wrong and tried to right it.

But if there is one thing that distinguished Andrei Dmitrovich Sakharov from other people who struggle to make this world a better place, it was his personal sacrifice for his beliefs. He could have accepted a life of privilege and official acclaim and like so many others, turned a blind eye to the injustice around him. But that was not his way. He accepted with great courage and humility the price he paid for being the conscience of his nation.

There are no words that will help blunt the pain you feel at your husband's death. I nevertheless hope you will be comforted by the knowledge that throughout the world the name Sakharov will live in the human heart as an example for us all to try to follow.
Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen press reports of the decisions referred to by Senator McKiernan, including some letters to the editor of a newspaper over the signature of Jim Crawley, the Executive Director of the Marriage Guidance Council of Western Australia. One of those letters included the incredible allegation or prophecy as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: WA soon won't have any counselling services under your Government's-
That is typical of the exaggeration that has accompanied what is a very difficult situation in providing funds for an important service in our community.

The fact is that there have been no cut- backs in funding to the Council during the period in office of the Hawke Labor Government. On the contrary, grants to the Council increased by 104.4 per cent during the past seven years-a 34.5 per cent increase in real terms, consistent with the overall increase of 36.8 per cent in real terms to all agencies for the same period. During the equivalent period of seven Liberal Budgets, all agencies received a real increase of only 4 per cent, and the grant to the Council actually decreased in real terms by 6.8 per cent. Those figures show a vivid contrast which, in fairness, ought to have formed part of the propaganda campaign mounted by Mr Crawley.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a Liberal candidate, wasn't he?

—I do not know whether that is the case, but perhaps I will take that on board. I still think that, at times, Mr Crawley has done excellent work on behalf of marriage guidance counselling in Western Australia, but in this particular instance he has gravely misled the people of Western Australia. I believe he has indicated his intention to resign his position in any case.
—He has not claimed that there have been cuts.

—His allegations of funding cuts by the Federal Government are not borne out, as the figures I quoted earlier clearly show. Mr Crawley has been unwilling to accept or understand the realities of funding for this very important area of government policy. Senator Chaney says that Mr Crawley has not talked about cuts. He stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Western Australia soon won't have any counselling services under your Government's present policies.

It seems to me that that could be the case only if there were severe cuts in Federal Government funding for marriage guidance counselling in Western Australia, and that is simply not the case. The case is that the Council received a marriage counselling grant for 1989-90 of $685,600-a 7.31 per cent increase on the 1988-89 grant and just under 9 per cent of the total marriage counselling budget. In addition, the Council received a grant of $20,000 to establish a new family mediation service, and a marriage education grant of $9,600.

The Council's increased income from fees for service has enabled the agency to decrease its dependence on Government grants from 94.9 per cent in 1982-83, to 61 per cent, which was the average for all funded agencies last year. The Council's very high level of annual growth-18.3 per cent real growth per annum-was maintained in the past two years by deficit budgeting. The agency now recognises that it cannot sustain a level of growth greater than that supported by the 34 per cent growth in Government grants, and has had to restrict its expansion.

An amount of $30,000 for Mandurah was included in the Council's current grant, a level sufficient to maintain that service until its funding can be re-examined next year. The Council opened the Midland service on its own initiative in April, fully aware that there was a risk it could not be funded in the current Budget.

The problems of the agency are exacerbated by an overall movement by marriage counselling services towards employing full time professional staff, rather than lay or sessional staff. I am sympathetic to the agency's need to take hard decisions, particularly its decision to dismiss sessional counsellors in order to produce a balanced budget. However, the Council has been considering this move for some years to reduce loss of its counsellors to better paid full-time professional positions. I do not believe that the present campaign waged by Mr Crawley either does justice to the very real support, particularly of the present Attorney-General, to marriage guidance counselling throughout Australia, or deals sufficiently with what is an Australian-wide phenomenon, namely, that there is a move to more professional full-time staff away from the lay and even volunteer staff that were for many years the backbone of many of these agencies. It is a difficult move because it means the loss of staff who have dedicated much of their lives to achieving recognition of marriage counselling as a profession. But as one moves from well intentioned persons to full professionals with a great deal of expertise in this field of human relations, then it is inevitable that the sort of restructuring undertaken by the marriage guidance service in Western Australia will continue.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CHANEY

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a letter dated 5 December which I understand was sent to all members of Parliament by the Marriage Guidance Council of Western Australia Inc. which sets out the views over Mr Crawley's signature and a statement of the financial situation of the Marriage Guidance Council. Mr Crawley has been identified as an ex-Liberal candidate, which goes back some time, and because this letter makes it clear that the public allegation is not a cut in funding but a cut in services because the Council could not get the increased funding that it sought from the Commonwealth, I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Marriage Guidance Council of Western Australia

I have to write to tell you that the Marriage Guidance Council has been forced to make major cuts to its marriage counselling services. These cuts are due to Commonwealth funding this financial year being $174,000 less than the amount the Council had indicated to the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department as being the amount necessary to maintain its present level of services.
A number of staff members who have been made redundant have indicated that they will write to their Federal M.P.; this letter is to brief you about the situation.
The Council can only reduce its expenditure by reducing staffing; and any reduction in counselling staff results in a corresponding reduction of income from counselling fees.
To achieve a balanced budget in 1989-90, the Council has had to:
close two counselling centres in Mandurah and Midland;
retrench its entire team of 25 part-time counsellors;

These measures, which will reduce the Council's marriage counselling capacity from 12,500 to 7,800 counselling interviews per year (i.e. by some 40 per cent), will enable the Council to operate within its available income for the first time for many years. Had this action not been taken, the Council would have accumulated a deficit in excess of $160,000 by the end of this financial year.
The action has not been taken lightly; an independent financial consultant's advice was obtained to ensure that no other alternative was being overlooked.
enormous waiting lists will develop-in fact the Council's waiting lists will be closed for some months to come-meaning that many hundreds of couples will not get the counselling they seek;

25 counsellors, some of whom have been with the Council for many years, who have in many instances paid for their own training as marriage counsellors, and who have been employed for years at exploitative salary levels are now redundant; their talent and their commitment to the community is lost.

The Commonwealth Government's ``saving'' of $160,000 on the funding of this organisation this year will result in an increased payment by the Australian taxpayer of at least $1,000,000-and probably twice that amount. This is in addition to the human suffering caused by broken marriage and family relationships that could have been avoided.
It is also pertinent to recall that marital breakdown is the second major cause of child poverty in Australia, and is a major causative factor in youth homelessness.

As this Council has pointed out repeatedly over recent years-backed up by the National Marriage Guidance Council of Australia-the present approach to funding of marriage counselling is completely inadequate. A telephone check this morning indicated that all constituent organisations of the National Marriage Guidance Council of Australia are building up deficits and/or reducing services. Additional funding in recent years for marriage counselling has been spread widely and thinly, presumably for political purposes, rather than being used to address the fundamental problems.
I would like to finish with one example, which is a telling one.

Base-grade counsellors in the WA Family Court are paid on a salary scale $36,618 to $40,554 p.a. This compares with a salary for base-grade counsellors in this organisation of $21,547 to $29,858. That this Council has been able to maintain its level of service in recent years is due to the dedication of its staff; but we have now, sadly, reached the end of the road.
I would be happy to answer any questions you might have.
P.S. I enclose a copy of a cutting from today's ``West Australian'' and my ``Letter to the Editor'' in response.
The enhancement of marriage and family life in their various forms through counselling, education and social policy formation.
MARRIAGE GUIDANCE COUNCIL OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA INC
For some years the Council has been attempting to maintain, and even to increase, the volume of marriage counselling undertaken, and to do so on an inadequate funding base.

Despite the temporary lull brought about by the introduction of fees for counselling, the problem of attempting to do more with our income than is in reality possible remains. Each year the financial deficit the Council has to juggle grows bigger.

For the present financial year, the Council indicated to the Commonwealth Government that it would need an increase in grant of some $170,000 to maintain its existing services (including the Bunbury Centre, to which we were committed).

An increase in grant of the size requested has not been forthcoming, and it has become apparent over the last three weeks that we face a considerable financial crisis in the form of a deficit of $161,000 on our operating budget. Even this figure is misleading because it is arrived at after cutting corners-for example, not paying the 3% occupational superannuation we are morally obliged to pay, not making provision for long service leave or depreciation, etc.

The Management Committee, mindful of this situation, requested me to prepare a `balanced budget' on at least a cash basis-this is, a budget that would not show a deficit of income over expenditure even though items like long service leave and depreciation would not be provided for. In making this request, two other factors that are likely to affect the Council over the next two years or so were also taken into account. First, the general economic situation and high interest rates, which would make it extremely difficult, if not impossible, for the Council to cope with a large overdraft. Second, there are serious moves afoot for the Council to be covered by an industrial award-and the likely conditions of an award would precipitate a crisis for the Council given the corners we have been cutting in some areas, notably the basis on which we pay sessional counsellors.
At a meeting last night, the Executive Committee of the Council adopted a final budget for the year which does not allow for a deficit.
The consequences of this budget are as follows:

(i) The Midland and Mandurah Centres will close for the rest of this financial year, with effect from 23 December. The premises will be retained until we know the level of Commonwealth funding for 1990/91.
(ii) No sessional counsellors will be employed after the end of 1989.
(iii) Counselling interns may continue their training up to the point of accreditation if they wish.
(iv) Staff counsellors at Midland and Mandurah will be offered the option of working at West Perth and Fremantle respectively.
(v) The staffing of reception at West Perth will be reorganised to achieve cost savings.
(vi) The West Perth and Fremantle Centres will be open only two nights per week from 1 January 1990.

I deeply regret having to make these cuts to our services. Not least because people's jobs and livelihoods are affected. They are, however, inevitable: we have gone as far as we can for as long as we can trying to manage our service on a totally inadequate funding base.
Individual letters will be sent to all staff members personally affected.
A meeting for all staff has been called for 5.15 p.m. tomorrow, Thursday 30 November, so that I can explain matters in more detail and answer any questions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH-EASTERN FORESTS OF NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Resources seen reports of statements by the South East Forest Alliance (SEFA) that it has withdrawn from the regional consultative committee which the Government is setting up to help to establish a sustainable, environmentally efficient forest industry in south-eastern New South Wales? Has SEFA yet told the Minister why it has made this decision? Can the Minister advise honourable senators what are SEFA's reasons for its decision? Is he yet in a position to advise the Senate what impact SEFA's decision will have on the work and objectives of the regional consultative committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald stating that environmental groups have decided not to be part of the consultative committee that I have established to advise the Government on what action it should take in view of reports that are imminent on various aspects of forest management and environmental concerns in the south-eastern forests of New South Wales. However, it is unfortunate that, like the occasion when SEFA released its so-called peace plan, SEFA has not approached me with any reasons why it made this decision. Therefore, it is not competent for me to advise at first-hand what its reasons might be, although I do note a press report by one of its spokespersons that, in view of the loss by SEFA of a court application against the New South Wales Forestry Commission, we should now take action under the corporations power to achieve an outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: The concern I have is that this week we are expecting a report from a team led by Professor Bryant Richards that has been studying the flora and fauna properties of the south-eastern forests. It will be an interim report. It appears likely that the team will require more time to complete its full report, and this Government has not put any restraint on its time. It believes that the report should be consistent with the scientific integrity of the reporting team. However, the interim report will be a significant step towards getting in place all the information base necessary to make a long range plan for the management of the south-eastern forests.

Early next year we will receive a report from consultants on the viability of a flitchmill process in the south-east, and a further report into the better use of small and round wood-material that would normally be left or burnt on the forest floor. So we are looking at efficient use of the basic resource. As well, early next year we will get a report on proposals for further value adding to the sawmill process. I also announced just a few weeks ago a consultancy which will look at the promotion of plantations in order to generate an alternative resource in the south-east of New South Wales with a specific focus on encouraging farmers to use part of their marginal farmland as a plantation resource for industry on a guaranteed buy-back basis as well as broad acre plantation cropping for the south-east.

It was intended that all those reports would come to a regional consultative committee, comprising unions, loggers, woodchippers, environmental groups, the community, the New South Wales Forestry Commission and the Federal Government. That regional committee would not be a voting but an advising body. Its purpose would be to consider those reports and make recommendations to the Government on how best to manage the entire resource from both an environmental and a forestry point of view. It now appears from what is being said in the media that we are being requested to abort that process and proceed to a new process. I think it is appropriate for me to say that we want the consultative council process to be the means by which we decide what the long range managerial plans for that area should be and how we meet the environmental aspirations of the community as well as protect the future livelihood of the up to 700 families whose futures depend on a viable timber industry in that area.

More importantly, perhaps, we also want to see a timber industry that efficiently utilises the resource at its disposal and develops a whole industry plan, which means that we stop exporting the cheapest commodity-woodchips-and start exporting more value added commodities to earn more on our trade account and provide a future career for people in the sawmill industry.

So I am disappointed that SEFA has taken this action. I hope it will see the value in joining the consultative council and will recognise that we are in a period of transition from the old, wasteful way of managing that forest to an efficient way of managing it. In fact, we are now doing many of the things that SEFA put up in its peace plan and in a way which meets environmental objectives as well.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Peter Baume proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The extra opportunities for families and children under the Liberal/National Parties' Economic Action Plan.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is directed to the future. It is directed to the brighter future for families and children promised by the Economic Action Plan of the coalition parties. That Economic Action Plan carries with it a message of hope; a message of what might be; a message of new opportunity; and a message of a better future. It is a promise of more self-sufficiency; of greater control over our own lives; of more choices; and of new financial support for those choices under a new Liberal and National parties coalition government.

SPEECH.PARA: This discussion is not about the past nor is it about the present, and it will not involve any denigration of any kind of those things that the present Government has done. Those things have been done and those initiatives have been taken, generally with the support of the Opposition parties. The benefits which were enjoyed by certain groups have had the backing of all sections of the Parliament. So we do not object to them and we will not criticise them. But, to the extent that the Australian Labor Party's approach has been limited to certain categories of people, it has ignored the needs of others. Labor's values have been reflected in the policies. They have been reflected in the ways its policies have worked, whom they have supported, for whom they have made things easier, whom they have not supported, and for whom they have made things a whole lot more difficult.

We do not contest that some people have been assisted. It would be churlish to do so. It is unnecessary to do so. But equally it would be churlish and improper for Government speakers to deny some other parts of the current picture, especially in relation to measures of continuing need yet to be addressed by the Government. First, it would be churlish of Government speakers to deny that some groups have not had much benefit from Labor Government initiatives. Second, it would be churlish of Government speakers to deny that many Government policies, including major economic, fiscal and monetary policies, have contributed in a major way to the difficulties that families face and to the hardships with which they are attempting to cope.

My colleagues will deal with particular parts of the picture and will indicate where our approach will be better. Senator Messner will concentrate on the economic burdens on families and children-on the direct contributions to family hardship, to poverty, to need, and to failure to cope which have been produced by the Labor Government's actions. Senator Messner will indicate where our action plan will assist these groups. Senator Reid will discuss some aspects of family dissolution. She will discuss some of the ways in which family breakdown contributes to child poverty and to difficulties for families. She will outline some of the financial burdens which have been aggravated under Labor, which themselves have contributed so much to family stress and breakdown. She will indicate how these burdens will be eased when the Liberal and National Economic Action Plan is put into effect. I will discuss some aspects of our plans to provide new opportunities and options for the care of children.

Recently I had the privilege of opening a new private child-care facility-a facility at which most places had already been taken. The audience contained many parents-men and women-whose children used that centre. The women, incidentally, were part of the new Australia. They represented a significant change that has occurred, a change which now sees many Australian women working in paid employment as a matter of deliberate choice. As Senator Amanda Vanstone has pointed out, we Liberals recognise, we accept and we would support-just as we would wish to support all other women who make different choices-the women who have made this move and this choice to continue in paid employment. We also support those Australian women who choose to stay at home to care for young children.

Be that as it may-I come back to the child-care facility-I saw many men and women there who were in paid employment. For families with both parents in paid employment, or for single-parent families with that parent in paid employment, child-care is not an optional extra, it is not a luxury; it is a necessity. The parents with whom I spoke, the young people I know, all wish to have children but because of the economic problems that couples face many have had to put off having a family in order to secure their economic future. Many parents have also found that they must both continue to work after their children are born. They have found that they need two incomes if they are to own a home and maintain their families as they were taught to do by their own parents. As I say, they do wish to have and to care for children. They do wish to discharge their role as citizens and as caring family members. They care very much about their children and about the welfare of those children. They need access to child-care in one or more of its forms to enable them to discharge this duty. It was apparent when I opened this particular private child-care facility that for many of those parents child-care had generally not been available where they needed it and when they needed it, and had not been available in the form in which they needed it. In part that is because the Labor Government is not interested in them and in the kind of child-care facilities they are seeking. This means that it has been more difficult for them to be good parents; more difficult for them to organise their families as they wish to do; more difficult for these men and women to make for their own children the best provision within the situation in which so many of them work, and are forced to work because of economic policies which are not of their making but for which they have to suffer.

It has been the same for many years. I remember 20 or so years ago that my wife and I had young children and we required access to child-care from time to time. It was wonderful if we could turn to our families-to our extended family-to get access to that child-care, but we could not always do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mobile families cannot.

—As Senator Newman says, mobile families cannot. Child-care is an absolute necessity. But in those days, a generation ago, it was devilishly difficult for us to find access to child-care for our children. Our friends at that time who were looking for full day care, long day care, occasional care, after school care or vacation care found the task almost impossible. The problem has not disappeared; it has not disappeared in a generation or two generations. Parents know this, and this is why so many parents have given so much support and have welcomed so much the program and proposals of the Opposition. The coalition's plans in the area of child support are to build upon, to extend, to complement what the Labor Government has done-not to abandon it, not to replace it, but to augment what already exists. We intend to redress some of the unnecessary imbalances which have characterised the approach of Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: Because this Government has concentrated on poorer families and on single parent families-as I said, most of the measures have had our support-we intend to offer new programs, new support, and new opportunities to classes of parents and their children who have been largely ignored in the past seven years. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The cost of that initiative, that is, the initiative to introduce a series of tax rebates for families caring for children, will be $1,000m each year. That is a very significant contribution to the support of Australian families. Secondly, under the Liberal-National Party's Economic Action Plan we will adjust the arrangements for the dependent spouse rebate to ease the benefit withdrawal where extra income is earned and we will raise the threshold below which the full rebate can be claimed. Thirdly, and this brings me back to the question of child-care, we will make expenditure on child-care tax rebatable-$20 per week for the first child under five years of age and $10 per week for each other child-for families with at least one parent in paid employment. We have made it rebatable because that is a fairer system of tax expenditure; fairer than making it tax deductable.

SPEECH.PARA: It was just a couple of years ago that women were taking the Australian Taxation Commissioner to court to try to obtain some kind of tax relief for the child-care expenses they were incurring for the services they required. Labor opposed these women in the courts as recently as a few years ago.

As part of our policy we now propose to make expenditure on child-care tax rebatable. This new Liberal-National Party approach will leave maximum power and maximum autonomy in the hands of the parents. It will provide more flexibility. It will allow the development of more child-care places than at present. It will confer more benefit on many children than is presently possible. It does not matter whether a little child's parents are poor or wealthy; what is needed are the very best services here, now, where and when they are required. Parents will decide, in the light of their own circumstances, where they wish to enrol their children and where they wish to incur costs.

Of course, the proposed new subsidy will cover only part of the costs; parents will still have to find some part. But the arrangement we have proposed will improve markedly what exists today. It will be a major improvement for parents with young families. It is a declaration of coalition values and priorities. It complements rather than replaces the existing arrangements. It will create many winners amongst Australian parents and children.

I point out that when we were able to get some feedback from the public about our Economic Action Plan, this feature was one of the most appreciated and most welcome. The Government has to recognise something that it often ignores: being active and busy is not the same as being effective. It is not just a question of how many places are being provided; it is also a question of how many places are still needed, of how many places have not been provided for parents wanting child-care. SPEECH.PARA: So we are not unduly impressed by accounts of all that the Government has done or by promises of what it might do in the future if it had the opportunity. Neither are we terribly impressed by some boring recitations of inputs: how many dollars have been promised; how many dollars have been spent; how many programs have been announced for some time in the future and so on-such as the Government's promise to end child poverty in about 12 days from now.

TALK.START.PARA: —They've had their chance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are asked to acknowledge and pay credence to the Opposition's Economic Action Plan. The words of the matter of public importance being discussed are:

SPEECH.PARA: The extra opportunities for families and children under the Liberal/National Parties' Economic Action Plan.

It is a plan which already has been discredited, with a shelf life, I suggest, shorter than Andrew Peacock's attention span. It is a plan which, in its genesis, was misguided; in its detail was wrong; on the major economic issues, was silent; and which is riddled with inequity. It is nothing more than a superficial attempt at policy development which reflects a lack of understanding of the major issues of the day by the Opposition leadership.

It is supposed to be an economic action plan, but let us look at where it takes us. What does it do about fiscal policy? What does it do about monetary policy or wages policy? In the words of Mr Peacock, `Who is to know'. On the major economic issues of the day we are offered a leap into darkness. It is promoted as an economic policy but it does not address economic issues. It is promoted as a tax policy but it contains no tax policy detail. As to interest rates, who is to know? Who do we believe? Do we believe Senator Stone and Dr Hewson, who say that there will be no change, do we believe Mr Peacock, who cannot believe himself or do we believe the body of economists who have no doubt that the Opposition's leap into darkness will lead to higher interest rates?

The Opposition's policy is one that, in any sense of the word, cannot withstand analysis. It is superficial, a policy whose shelf life-like that of the Leader of the Opposition-has already expired. Do members on the other side not wish that they had stuck with John Howard? It is a policy which essentially is one of catchy themes as a substitute for hard, serious policy analysis. It is based on market research, not on social research. Were the policy to be based on social research, we would have a degree of targeting which this Government has followed over the last seven years and one endorsed by Senator Chaney when he was Minister for Social Security in 1982 when he said:

. . . we should be approaching the problem in a way that tries to define the people who are in the difficult situation and directing assistance to them rather than universally increasing levels of assistance at very much greatly increased cost to all taxpayers . . .

An endorsement of the targeted policy that we have now. There is not even the pretence from the Opposition that it is serious about eliminating poverty in the community. Instead, there is a policy-a plan-designed to con the electorate, based on generalities, and there are reasons for this.

We shudder to think what else may be included on the Opposition agenda. On 25 July 1989 the Sydney Morning Herald published the contents of a secret letter from Mr Peacock to his shadow Ministers asking for a list of policies that should not be highlighted in the election campaign. There will be two sets of policies. There will be the sugar coating that Senator Peter Baume has talked about, the public list based on market research; and there will also be the secret hit list-a secret hit list which has already been leaked and exposed-based on ideological reaction to progressive social policy. Senator Peter Baume, having had experience of secret hit lists in recent days, should understand what they mean to the electorate. For instance, the people of New South Wales know full well what happens when a government with a secret hit list is elected. The action plan will be used as an excuse-as it was in New South Wales-to put social policy and social justice back 100 years.

The Opposition's policy is also unfair. When we are looking at assistance to families, and an overall policy, we have to look at who pays. We have to make sure that people pay according to their capacity to pay. In this respect the action plan which we have been asked to endorse will impact on families most unfairly. Under the Fraser-Howard-Hewson regime, tax avoidance and evasion were the only significant growth areas. Avoiders and evaders became rich while tens of thousands of families were thrown into poverty. We remember the figures-billions of dollars were involved in avoidance and evasion-and we know who paid then; it was the ordinary Australian taxpayer. It took a Labor Government to seriously tackle the integrity of the tax system. Central to that was the capital gains tax which took away the options for the wealthy to convert their taxable income into tax-free capital gains. The first figures on capital gains tax showed that less than one per cent of all taxpayers paid capital gains tax. In the corporate sector, only 2 per cent of taxable companies paid capital gains tax, and 85 per cent of all receipts came from fewer than 500 companies.

The Opposition plans to abolish the capital gains tax and replace it with a tax which will distort investment in this country and be most unfair. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out to highlight the inequity of the tax, it would involve a gift to the Liberal Party President, Mr John Elliott, worth millions of dollars. That is a saving against his contingent liability for capital gains tax. Who is to pay? The benefit-the tax subsidy-that Mr Elliott will get out of the Economic Action Plan of the Australian Liberal Party will be the equivalent of a full year's pension for over 1,500 age pensioners. If the Opposition is concerned about families and ordinary Australians, it should realise that they are the ones who will pay.

In terms of who is to pay, there is nothing more central to services for families-and Senator Peter Baume made this point-than medical services. We do not know who will pay in that respect, because Mr Peacock does not know. Not only does he say he does not know but he also refuses to spell out the principles which would guide the Opposition. What we do know is that we would be driven by the same bloody-minded ideological commitment to return us to those stop-start health policies of the Fraser-Howard years when no-one knew what was going on.

Health services are important, and wages are vitally important. Not only does the Leader of the Opposition not know what his wages policy means, but Opposition members when asked about the matter quite recently also time and again could give no commitment to ensuring the maintenance of the Industrial Relations Commission or minimum wages. In this very important and direct area of income to families the Opposition proposes to dispense with the protection which families receive through the industrial relations system. What will happen? There will be what there was in the mid-1970s. Very few will get a lot out of the system. Many more of the lower paid work force, and those with little labour market power, will see their incomes decimated in real terms. That is what happened during the Opposition's last term of office, and that is what it is offering again.

I leave the macro-economic policy for a moment and turn to what the Opposition promises in the very definite and closed area of family policy. I put aside for the moment the three important basic social measures of Medicare health services, wages policy and the fact that, under this Government, the most important family income support measure-employment-has been a major success and achievement of this Government in that 1.6 million jobs have been created during its term of office, and are still being created. What is the Opposition talking about in terms of social policy? The Opposition is very free with its talk of opportunities for families, but does it have any real idea of what that means? A true concern for families, as I said, includes the areas of health care, jobs, child-care and schools. A true concern for Australian families means a concern for a range of services and opportunities which only an integrated social policy can deliver.

The Opposition's action plan is silent on all these things. At the heart of the action plan is a series of tax giveaways based on market research. We are not getting that range of services and an adequate and comprehensive social policy based on good reason from the Opposition. The direction the Opposition will take is pretty clear. For an analysis of that direction we should refer to a statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in 1987. He said:

. . . it is just impossible with any credibility, to proclaim concern for families and then proceed to smash every part of the social infrastructure that determines the welfare of Australian families.
Yet that is a measure of our opponent's hypocrisy. That statement was true then and is even truer now because there is exactly the same hypocrisy in 1989.

For instance, the Opposition plans to discard on the scrap heap of special benefit thousands of unemployed families and their children. They will be condemned to poverty. We should not be surprised at that approach because, in every year of the last Government, 50,000 children of beneficiary families were added to the scrap heap. In its last year that Government added another 150,000. With that record, and more of the same promised, how can Senator Peter Baume talk with any degree of credibility of opportunities for families?

I mentioned jobs. Jobs are crucial for family opportunity, yet the Opposition of Senator Peter Baume left Australia in 1983 with an unemployment rate of 10.9 per cent. This Government has reduced that by creating 1.6 million new jobs. More importantly, it has also reduced the number of long term unemployed-those who would, once again, deliberately be consigned to the scrap heap under the Opposition's policy. The number of such unemployed was reduced from 108,000 in 1983 to 47,000 in 1989. If we are really looking at areas of need and high poverty concentration, we are looking at the long-term unemployed.

One cannot underestimate the importance to people in the community of health care and health services. Access to cheap, quality health care is crucial to creating opportunities for Australian families as we move into the 1990s. Yet, as I have said, there has not been a concise or clear statement or costing from the Opposition on its health care policy. We know-and Mr Shack, the Opposition spokesperson on health has made it clear in private meetings-that the Opposition wants to abolish Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's rubbish. Try telling the truth and see whether you get used to it.

—It has been spelt out; the Leader of the Opposition refuses to guarantee that Australian families will not pay more, and Senator Puplick cannot run away from that. If Senator Puplick knows what is going on in Andrew Peacock's mind he is better off than he is. I repeat, the Leader of the Opposition refuses to guarantee that Australian families will not have to pay more for Medicare but he refuses, as does Senator Puplick, to give any firm details. It is no wonder, because the Opposition's record in this area is appalling. In 1983, low income families--
—You are an absolute fraud.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask that that remark be withdrawn.
—Yes, I ask Senator Puplick to withdraw that statement.
—I withdraw that remark.

—The Opposition's record on health is quite well known. In 1983, low income families paid 7 per cent of their incomes on health care. Under Labor most low income families get health care free through Medicare, and the maximum that is necessary to be paid is 1.25 per cent. It is worth noting, when we address this issue, when we address what the Opposition is creating to be a problem for itself, that over 71 per cent of Australians now support the continuation of Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of basic essential family policies, the Opposition cannot turn away from education. What would be of greater concern to Australian families than educating their children? Retention rates here are a great benchmark and indicator of this Government's performance in this area. We have increased year 12 retention rates to 61 per cent. When we came into government they were a lamentable 36 per cent.

These issues-jobs, health care, and education-are just some of the issues which must be addressed if the Opposition is to come in here and tell us about the adequacy of its Economic Action Plan, and that it wants to improve the opportunities available to Australian families. Yet on this whole range of issues it is very silent.

I have not mentioned the extra 58,000 child-care places this Government has introduced; I have not mentioned the 3.7 million children who are attracting family allowance or the 1.2 million children who are attracting family allowance supplement or its equivalent; I have not mentioned the spread of superannuation, with all that it means for family savings and retirement; and I have not mentioned this Government's further commitment to new tertiary education places, to new child-care places, to more public housing and to better health. On those crucial social policy issues, the Opposition is once again silent. It is quite apparent that it is concealing an agenda which does not promise families opportunities. It basically promises devastation of the infrastructure that is there to assist families in this country. This is clear from its record and the little it has said today.

Let us look at another part of the Opposition's record in this area, before I go on to an objective assessment of its Economic Action Plan. Basically, what it was able to do in the past was to ensure that people remained dependent on social services. In 1975 there were 30.9 people dependent on income support for every 100 people in the work force. In seven short years it managed to raise that to 43.7-43.7 mothers, fathers and children trapped in the social security system. This Government has reduced it back to 1975 levels-to 33.6 per cent. That is hundreds of thousands of families who have been lifted from dependence on social security. The consequent effect of that, of course, is benefits to the taxpayer as well. Let us bear that in mind. But the Opposition comes in here and puts this particular proposal. Suffice it to say that the heartland of the Opposition's support is the rural sector, or so it claims. Let us go to the Country Women's Association of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you deal with the kids who have got nowhere to sleep at night?

—On that point, I have experienced that a lot more than Senator Puplick ever will. The Country Women's Association makes a very clear and definite point and one that Senator Puplick should let permeate through his thick outer shell. A report in the Australian Rural Times of 19 October says:

SPEECH.PARA: `It seems more money will go to the more successful families and less money will go to the less successful families,' said Mrs Jean Tom, the national CWA president. `Just because children live in rural areas doesn't mean to say that they shouldn't have the same opportunities as city children.'

It recognises the gross inequity in the Opposition's proposals. It recognises that support needs to be targeted. It recognises that the Government's approach has been quite fundamentally important in that area. We have targeted areas of need and we have addressed them. We have done that in a rational comprehensive way and in a scientific way, based on social policy, not on market research.

In reality what we have on the other side is an Opposition desperate to win the middle ground out there. There is a constant search for popular sentiment, even though, as we see almost daily, popular sentiments do not necessarily fit into serious policy making. No-one within the Opposition is doing the serious work designed to meet the social and economic challenges of the 1990s and the next century. That is what distinguishes this Government from the Opposition. That is why the community will say two things to us: `We cannot trust Andrew Peacock to deliver' and `We think Senator Chaney is going to be disastrous'-and they probably would say not much better about Senator Puplick. The Opposition knows that and that is why it is quiet. It made the mistake and dumped Howard. It replaced him with a bloke whose motto is not `Read my lips' but `Follow my eyelashes'-and they flutter all over the place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before us today proclaims:

SPEECH.PARA: The extra opportunities for families and children under the Liberal/National Parties' Economic Action Plan.

The most important thing to do in this debate is to ask the question, and attempt to answer it: Which families and which children? We will need to look at the plan and attempt to answer that question. In essence, much of the comment at the time and subsequent to the announcement of the Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan does answer that question. One comment which has recently been published in the news magazine of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) is that of its president, Merle Mitchell, saying that the plan is `unfair, hypocritical and economically damaging', and that it:
. . . represents a blatant attack on the most disadvantaged people in Australia: the jobless, recently-arrived immigrants, aborigines, students, and sick and disabled people.

I would add to that, people living in the country. Obviously, a family with children who do not come into any of those categories might have some positive things to say in this debate, but that is quite a long list. The ACOSS analysis goes on to say:
. . . the . . . proposals are badly targeted. They will fundamentally damage both the economy and the victims of our current economic difficulties.

As I said, a good deal of the comment at the time was similar, in essence, to that kind of approach. Indeed, upon announcement of the package, Ross Dunn made this point in the Australian Financial Review:

The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, shifted the Liberal Party significantly to the right yesterday by asking the most disadvantaged groups to suffer the burden of a decision to focus more government spending on families.
Those with the least ability to pay-
we have the same list-
the unemployed, Aborigines, migrants and students-will be targeted for big spending cuts to boost the incomes of families, under the Opposition's tax policy.

When Ross Dunn mentions families, obviously he is not including the families of those groups of disadvantaged. So the only conclusion can be that if the matter of public importance read, `The opportunities for families not in disadvantaged categories', maybe we could see some under this plan.

To look at the taxation measures in the Economic Action Plan, I will deal first with those taxation measures which relate to payments for families directed towards children, where we have the child tax rebate and child-care rebate. Obviously, there are positive things which Senator Peter Baume has said and which can be said for a rebate system of this kind. The concern centred around this part of the package has been that the rebates certainly do not cover full costs and that the whole program, as outlined in the statement, actually looks to be costing more than the entire children's services program currently in place and there are no guarantees of extra child-care places. Clearly, certainly to the Australian Democrats, the provision of extra child-care places must be a priority. It is clearly not a priority under this scheme. It is really not so much what is there as what is not there that is of concern for those of us who are interested in increased provision of child-care in our community. That ought to be all of us, because full utilisation of the working capacity of all members of our community is essential if we are to improve our economic status.

Also, we need to look at who benefits from this particular package in terms of child-care. That point was made again by Kenneth Davidson. On 13 October in the Age he pointed out that the people who would benefit from that package of child payments would be mainly middle and upper two-income families. He then went on to comment on the capital gains tax changes, which I will move on to now. As has been well canvassed since the Economic Action Plan came forward, the Opposition is walking away from the current capital gains tax and putting forward a speculative gains tax option at a cost of $450m. This option will reduce the taxes paid by the wealthiest Australians, making capital gains tax optional.

If we look at the figures in respect of what has been happening with capital gains tax in its current form, we can see who benefits from this measure: 76 per cent of capital gains tax revenue in 1987-88 came from taxpayers with taxable incomes above $35,000 per annum; 62.3 per cent in that year came from taxpayers with taxable incomes of over $50,000; 28.3 per cent of that revenue came from taxpayers with incomes exceeding $500,000; and 14.4 per cent came from people in receipt of total income in excess of $2m. Clearly, this is a tax which will advantage the best off in our community. The windfall of $450m will go virtually exclusively into the pockets of the richest members of society-not least John Elliott-who in the past, and again in the future, it seems, under a Liberal-National government, have been notorious in escaping their taxation responsibilities. Under this Government, this group, which has escaped from the disadvantages of wage restraint and has been part of the economic picture in the time of the Hawke Government, has benefited greatly from the property and share boom and has received the biggest marginal tax rate cuts.

All of this has come about under the Hawke socialist-according to the Opposition-Government. Clearly, the Opposition's capital gains proposal would direct even more of the private sector energy into arranging and rearranging affairs to avoid the speculative gains tax, reopen the tax avoidance industry which flourished under the Liberals in the 1970s, distort investment decisions by encouraging investors to hold assets for tax reasons, and push more funds into longer term investments, such as property, at the expense of the share market and the investment that we need for active industrial and technological development in this country.

If we look at aspects of the Economic Action Plan involving spending-most of them really involve saving-we will see that unemployment is a major and significant item. I am a little bit surprised in that I have decided to quote Greg Sheridan on this matter. On 21 October in the Australian he made some interesting comments with which I concur. He says that the policy of removing the unemployment benefit from the long-term unemployed after nine months-there are a whole range of extra stringencies, in what is already a very stringent system-is confusing. I think this aspect of the confusion is worth putting on the record. He states:
After nine months your dole-
a term that I would prefer not to use myself, but I am quoting from Greg Sheridan-
will be stopped unless you qualify for a special benefit.
To qualify for the special benefit you will be interviewed by welfare bureaucrats.
Yet to qualify for the dole now you need regular interviews with bureaucrats.
That has been implemented very heavily by this Government with its work test. The article continues:
Where is the change?
Many of the long-term unemployed are in bad shape.

If these interviews are to involve intensive counselling, much less any rehabilitation or retraining, they will involve still more bureaucrats, an increase in the welfare state, and will save no money.
If the policy does not involve such extensive counselling I would say it would survive about three or four weeks of implementation.

He then goes on to picture a genuinely needy family-someone forced into beggary, prostitution or crime-appearing on the Jana Wendt or Derryn Hinch programs and showing up what is a heartless and actually unworkable Opposition policy. We also had a similar scenario put to us on 22 October by Paul Lyneham in the Melbourne Sunday Sun in which he pointed out the devastating effects that the Opposition's proposals would have on the long-term unemployed. He saw the development of a whole new group of people in our community. In a very ironic way he suggested that this might actually turn into a tourist attraction with the reinstitution of beggars in the streets. In particular, he said that tourists could be taken out into the country to see colourful swaggies sitting around the campfire. He also suggested that it would be even more colourful if we could teach the long-term unemployed a little of Banjo Paterson. In his article Paul Lyneham stated:

Suddenly a drive into the country could be a whole new experience for the kids. It would also be a winner with Japanese tourists, especially if some of the long-termers could learn a bit of Banjo Paterson.
These are scenarios that really do not bear thinking about; nevertheless, they certainly are there. The Australian Council of Social Service, in its analysis, stated:

Of the $1,500 million the Coalition aims to save by cutting off unemployment benefits after nine months, $835 million is budgeted to transfer 50 to 60 per cent of long-term beneficiaries onto Special Benefit.
There remains, of course, a crucial question: what happens to the 40 to 50 per cent of jobless people and their families who will be denied Special Benefit?
That is the crucial question. In their own way, the other commentators are asking that question.

In the brief time I have available, I think I should address the question of Aboriginal families. Obviously they are the most disadvantaged people in our community. I think it is interesting that the Opposition spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs, Warwick Smith, has expressed concern about the depth of the cuts in this area which is one of the hardest hit sectors in this field. Mr Smith was quoted in the Melbourne Age on 13 October as saying:
My challenge is to improve administration and remove duplication . . .

We know what that means-Aboriginal affairs will go back to the States. We know what that means for Aboriginal people. This would be against the wishes of the Australian people who have said that this is a national responsibility. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 October the Chairman of the New South Wales Aboriginal Legal Service, Mr Paul Coe, stated:
. . . cuts in funds for Aboriginal legal services would result in greater numbers of Aborigines in jails because many would not get proper representation.

We know that there is a major problem with Aborigines in gaols. The policy is described as `genocidal' by Ms Linda Burney of the New South Wales Aboriginal Education Consultative Group. So we must be concerned about that area.

What about students? The Government's proposal is being taken that one step further. As is pointed out by Kenneth Davidson in the Age of 13 October, the revenue that will be generated by this version of charging for basic tertiary education will be used to fund the promised concessions to middle and upper income groups rather than expand tertiary education funding. At least we can say that this Government has targeted its charges in respect of students into increased education funding. I think that is something that this Opposition should be condemned for.

I have mentioned that country people will be disadvantaged by the Opposition's Economic Action Plan. The disturbing thing is that we have an economic package from the Opposition which does nothing to address the question of interest rates. I did not think I would be standing here quoting Ross Gittins but he talks about the unstated part of the policy which is continuing high interest rates. All Australian families have to be concerned and are concerned about that. Under the Opposition's policies, rural families will have their basic services to rural areas cut. Their country link will go as will their rural counselling service, access to education and training programs. It is very difficult to see which families will actually be advantaged by this policy. As Greg Sheridan said, it is a policy of mirrors. It is a policy which has many costs built into it. Obviously, those costs will have to be met by further cuts in basic community and public services-health, education and housing. As this policy gets more exposure I am sure Australians will become more concerned about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support my distinguished colleague Senator Peter Baume in his constructive proposal for discussion today. Having just heard the Australian Labor Party and Australian Democrats speakers issue forth a barrowful of red herrings, we know that there is absolutely no substance to their argument because red herrings always throw such a smell across the trail. Those speakers have no points to debate today. As Senator Peter Baume has made abundantly clear, this policy, the Economic Action Plan, is directed to the future. It is about the future direction of policies in this country to strengthen, not weaken, Australian families. It offers security, not uncertainty. It is to support families, not to condemn them to lives of dismay leading to and bordering on despair. It is hope for the future that drives this country; it always has. In the practical world of Australian politics, that can be spelled out as one thing, which is quite clear in our policy-a fair go for all. Governments of whatever shade should direct their policies to that central theme to develop a future in which proper and relevant standards are encouraged and in which the common interest we all have in the success of the fair go is the cornerstone for a stronger, more prosperous Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us dwell on the point of common interest for a moment. Many people mistake the concern for families, expressed by many on this side of the Senate, as being nostalgic, old-hat and, cynically, even irrelevant to the needs of the people. Nothing can be further from the truth. Looking back to judge from where Australian families have come, we see that our policy is not a longing for a return to the good old days; it is to determine the extent of the changes that have occurred in Australian society since those days in order to recognise the needs for the society in the future, to spell out positive policies which address these needs, and to look forward to the increasing challenges to families as we enter the last decade of the twentieth century. This is to take the realistic view of the less than ideal state of Australian society. This is positive political action, capable of being undertaken by any government, even the Hawke Labor Government.

Let us take some examples of the future needs of Australian families resulting from a likely lower level of home ownership caused by high building costs and astronomical interest rates leading to a higher dependence on government supported housing: the decline in the role of the family and the extended family in caring for the aged; the pressures for income support in retirement-there we have the answer of reducing superannuation tax; a need for child-care caused by the economically driven entry of more women into the work force. We will offer tax deductions for child-care. In the past all these needs have been met by some degree of family support by government. But what of the future if that support is not so freely given by families because of pressures of divorce, separation, lack of security in housing or the need for two incomes in a family to pay the bills each week, to pay the taxes and the interest on the mortgage? They are the vital questions that go to the heart of our society, to the basis of political debate in this country, and to the rising scepticism of Australians towards Australian politicians and political processes.

These are the questions that the Liberal and National parties answer in their policies, particularly in the Future Directions statement which was put forward by John Howard last year, and more recently in the Economic Action Plan put forward by Andrew Peacock. These are the positive steps which a future Liberal and National party government must and will take. The commitment is there to meet the needs of the future based on a hard-headed assessment of the state of present day Australian society. Our policy statements are not mere rhetoric like the turgid recitation of Government initiated benefits in the past and such as we are surely going to hear later from Government speakers.

We do not deny that the Government has taken some action to assist families. We are not making cheap political points on the adequacy or otherwise of those actions. We have supported those in the past and we will support them in the future. That is not our complaint. Our point is very different. These recent government measures are redistributive measures. What the Australia of the future needs is direction to solve the cause of economic hardship. This is a contemporary imperative because of the crisis in the economic circumstances of families.

How has this crisis manifested itself in cold, hard statistical facts? Firstly, in the period of this Government since 1984-85, real disposable incomes have fallen sharply for all income units dependent on one income. The falls have ranged from $30.61 for single people to $47.85 for couples with four children. In the same period, the percentage of couples with children with both partners employed has risen from 46 per cent to 55 per cent of families. This growth in two-earner families indicates that some families have offset the falls in disposable income by increasing their participation in the work force. Thus, the recently rising trend of more women in the work force is economically driven; it is not necessarily a matter of free choice by spouses. So when the Government claims higher work force participation for women, in many cases this can be seen as `have to' rather than `want to'. This is where the Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan with child-care, children's rebates and dependent spouse rebates offers direct help now to alleviate these crises for battling families.

Secondly, housing has become significantly less affordable for families in the 17 years since 1972 of which Labor has governed for 10 long years. The Poverty Commission in 1972-73 found that 6.7 per cent of all income units then were below the poverty line after taking into account housing costs. But in 1985-86 under this Hawke Labor Government that figure doubled. This means that fewer people, particularly young people, can afford adequate housing than was the case 17 years ago. The reasons for higher housing costs have been well documented. We all know that it is associated with building costs caused by high regulation, especially in the labour market, and the obscene level of housing interest rates under the present Government's policies.

The Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan will address the crisis by attacking the causes such as the deregulation of the labour market and changes in work practices in Australian industry. We will introduce measures to help our export and import industries through the development of more competitive and efficient waterfront practices, better transport systems and the freeing up of the telecommunications industry. Finally, average income tax rates have risen under successive Labor governments. For instance, one-income families on average weekly earnings and with two children under 13 years of age have seen an increase of 6.9 per cent in their tax rate-that is an average tax rate-since 1976-77.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the marginal rate?

—The marginal rate is even higher in so far as it affects people on moderate incomes of around $20,000-a penalising rate of 40 per cent at the margin. It is a very big discouragement for people to work harder. But the picture we have here is that the economic changes in these three areas which the Government claims to be able to control have, firstly, increased housing mortgage payments to around 30 per cent of average weekly earnings from the long term average of 25 per cent--
—They didn't mention that, did they?

—The Government has not mentioned that, as Senator Peter Baume points out. Secondly, they have reduced household disposable income by substantial amounts-upwards of $50 per week-since 1985, particularly for one-income families with four children. Thirdly they have imposed higher and higher average rates of income tax on the average weekly earner. It is no wonder that families are battling in Australia today. It is no wonder that spouses are now entering the work force to a greater extent than ever before. It is not because of choice-although we do not deny the choice; that is very much a feature of our policies. Clearly, there is an economic imperative for people to enter the work force which is evident from the statistics I have cited. It is no wonder that people are looking for an alternative direction for the future. It is no wonder that people have received so warmly the Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan. This policy shows that the future direction for the Australian Government is to deal with this emerging crisis for families. That is why, at the first available opportunity, Australians will elect a new Liberal- National Party Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the following matter of public importance is being debated:

SPEECH.PARA: The extra opportunities for families and children under the Liberal/National Parties' Economic Action Plan.
