Even by quite a narrow definition, there are currently something like 40,000 long term-that is, for nine months or more-unemployment benefit recipients, about a quarter of the total, who have between them nearly 90,000 dependent children. They are the very families who are going to receive no assistance whatsoever from the Opposition's system of taxation rebates.

It has taken a long time for the Opposition to bring forth what it sees, apparently, as the solution to the need, for example, for children's services. I do not doubt the Opposition's sincerity for one second, but the Opposition's solution is extremely inadequate. Senator Peter Baume went into considerable detail about the unmet need, but he did not give any indication whatsoever how this unmet need was to be resolved. Certainly there are fewer occasional child-care places, out of school care places or long day care places than we would wish. It was not until 1972 that child-care even got a place on the political agenda. I can recall Mr Peacock, when he was Minister for Labour and National Service, introducing the outline of a child-care program just before the election at the end of 1972. Child-care was truly on the political agenda after the Whitlam Government came to power, it faltered under the Fraser Government and it has taken off again under Hawke. In 1983, we inherited 46,000 child-care places. By 1992, that figure will have increased by nearly 100,000 places, but it is clear that that is nowhere near enough. We have carefully crafted and funded plans to increase the number of child-care places in a way that will slowly but surely fulfil requirements.

What is the coalition going to do? There are no details, and we can only infer that the Opposition is planning to see the number of places increase as a result of the greatly increased private for profit sector, which we know at this stage does not fulfil the requirements of people, certainly not those on low incomes. The Opposition's policy does not provide care for very young children, care for which there is an enormous demand. It certainly does not provide care for children with special needs, disabilities, language and behaviour problems, for children in low income communities and rural areas. Is Senator Peter Baume honestly saying that we should go the way of the 1950s and 1960s-encouraging the private nursing home sector, pouring government money into the private for profit sector, with very little control about where places will be provided, at what standard places will be provided and what needs they will fulfil? After many inquiries we have all the evidence in the world that this is not the way to go, not the way to fulfil community needs for child-care or anything else.

Tax rebates, which will cost an enormous amount-about five times what we are currently spending on our community child-care system-are an extremely inefficient way to try to redistribute this sort of money. It is a reduction, of course, in the amount of tax that a person has to pay. The rebate is the same regardless of the level of income, provided tax liability exceeds the value of the rebate. People on very low incomes, including those in part time work for which they receive less than $5,000 or $6,000 a year, will get no rebate. Assuming a rebate per family of $2,000 per year, a family receiving $19,000 per year and one receiving $50,000 per year would each receive $2,000 per year. This does not look like horizontal equity to me. It is better than tax deduction in terms of equity, but on many measures of fairness it would still remain inequitable. Would it be fair, for example, that a wealthy parent in a luxurious city apartment who could afford to advertise for a live-in nanny at a wage of $250 a week plus keep would get the same assistance from Mr Peacock as a struggling sole parent on $15,000 a year. There are many reasons why rebates are inequitable and inefficient as a way of assisting people who need some extra help with their families. We have taken a number of extremely important initiatives, and I am glad that most of the speakers on the opposite side have acknowledged that. Those are measures which will continue, which will expand, and which we have guaranteed to index. Where is the Opposition's guarantee of indexing anything at all, I ask Senator Peter Baume?

The disadvantages in rebates and other such options are many and varied, but I would like to get these on record. An intelligent debate is occurring at last, and I am glad to see that it is being encouraged. Firstly, if financial assistance is available only to families already using child-care and not to those outside trying to get in, it is not at all clear how the supply of child-care places will be improved. I am one of those people who are completely in the dark as to how that supply of child-care places is to be improved by the coalition's policies. We all agree that improvement is absolutely essential. Secondly, there is no guarantee that cash available through tax options will actually be spent on child-care. Certainly, it does not necessarily go to the caring parent, it goes to the earner in what the Opposition believes is a typical single income, nuclear family; nor is it evident that such a general benefit could provide sufficient financial support for less well off families, given the cost of child-care. Thirdly, these options could have an inflationary effect and push up the price of child-care, thereby negating any benefits which might accrue-one of the very real dangers of depending upon market forces for such an essential community service.

Fourthly, rebates are open to abuse in so far as people using unpaid family arrangements may attempt to claim a benefit when no cost is actually incurred. Once again, this is a very real danger in the Opposition's suggestion of rebating expenditure on child-care. Fifthly, supply would be totally market driven and there would be no guarantee that the needs of disadvantaged groups would be met. That is, there is no needs-based planning, and I have already touched upon that. Sixthly, major disruptions would occur if the present service-based system of funding was fully or partially replaced by a tax option. As far as we know from the coalition's policies, this is its only response. Seventhly, a further consideration for any government would be the open-ended nature of taxation benefits. It would be very difficult to predict the costs and contain them to budget.

Women have been given a very high priority in all of our strategies. We have sought to broaden the choices available to women through the expansion of job opportunities and child-care. Amongst the many people who have been assisted by the wide range of policies are sole supporting parents. They do not seem to get much of a look in, in the coalition's policies those who are dependent or even partly dependent on social security. Is the jobs, employment, and training (JET) scheme one of the programs that the Opposition is planning to abolish? I note that Newstart and Skillshare are to be phased out. Through JET a substantial number of women are back into education or training, or into work. This has made substantial changes to the percentage of sole mothers who are employed. For the first time ever, in 1989 more than half of all sole mothers are employed: that is nearly 52 per cent, as against 39 per cent who were employed when we came to government in 1983.

Until recently, only about 25 per cent of sole parent pensioners received any support from the other parent. Our child support scheme has been introduced to overcome this problem, and there are now 20,000 custodial parents receiving an average of $100 per month through our child support scheme. This makes a great difference to their disposable income, but it is an issue that, apparently, has been completely overlooked by the coalition in its concern for extra opportunities for families with children. By definition, of course, there are children in all of these families. The proportion of sole parent pensioners receiving child support has increased from 25 per cent to over 35 per cent in the relatively short period since June 1988 when this scheme started. Sole parents are increasingly independent. For women, generally, there are growing opportunities. Disposable household income is ever-increasing, as I made quite clear during a similar debate last week. Over the last six years there has been an annual increase of 3 per cent in household income.

I really think it is time we put to bed this notion of women being conscripted. The economic imperative is there for men and women. Men and women work to support themselves and their families. Under the Labor Government, they have had a great many more opportunities of obtaining work and maintaining their families in dignity. We will continue along the way we have started, with tried and true programs that we have set in place and are continuing to implement. We are maintaining our commitment to the families of Australia in a way that the coalition does not seem even to have grasped and apparently has no intention of extending.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the significant things under Labor is the added pressure placed on marriages because of Labor's economic policies and their consequences. Marriages are breaking down at an alarming rate. The divorce statistics have risen from 39,800 in 1985 to 41,007 in 1988. Of those divorces, 17,422 were of couples who had no children and 23,585 were of couples with children. It is those children that I am particularly concerned about. In addition to the single parent families that come about as a result of divorce, there are those which come about as a result of the death of a parent. The latest figures on family structures show that 8 per cent of household are made up of one parent families. The vast majority of those parents of course are women. They make up about 90 per cent of the 330,000 or so people receiving the sole parent benefit as at last June.

There is no doubt that family breakdown results in enormous economic and social costs. One can only wonder at a government which does not require more effort to be put into making marriages work when one considers the enormous costs of dealing with the marriages once they have failed. The amount of money that is put into marriage counselling, teaching people about some of the aspects of marriage and living together, is paltry when one really looks at the number of divorces. As the statistics show, the costs are borne by women and children.

The study by the Institute of Family Studies in 1985 showed that, at the time of separation, dependent women-that is, women dependent on their husbands' salaries-tended to have relatively young children and husbands with higher incomes compared with women who supplemented their husbands' incomes or had their own income. These more independent women had usually passed the state where the children were particularly in need of parental care and were facing the cost of older children. The study showed that two-thirds of the women who had been dependent or merely supplemented their husbands' incomes, three years after separation, had household incomes which put them barely within 20 per cent of the Henderson poverty line. They found it difficult to re-enter the work force. Very few had uninterrupted work histories. They had taken one or more breaks to have and raise their children. Men were, and are, much more likely to have furthered their education during the marriage. Often the husband had done so while the wife worked and supported him while he pursued his education prior to embarking upon having a family. A man's further education was more likely to have allowed him much greater career mobility than the wife. The report concluded that the time spent at home caring for children had substantially depreciated income earning potential. I do not think any of us would doubt that in the slightest.

The cost to women of performing the function of rearing children is realised in a very significant way at the time of a dissolution of a marriage. We then have a group of women with children to house, feed and clothe, with minimal opportunity to resume their education, to improve their qualifications or to gain employment. There are many disincentives in the system as it presently operates to their doing so. A women is frequently deterred from obtaining employment for fear of what will become of the children if they get sick or because she does not know when she will be able to get back on social security. Likewise with education. The disincentives that operate at present are enormous. As a consequence, many of these women and children are living in poverty. That cannot be denied. Certainly the Prime Minister cannot deny it and it will not change in the next 13 days. The numbers are increasing.

In addition to that we have the number of homeless young Australians. Although one might be able to argue about the number, it is obvious that there are no fewer than about 25,000 young homeless Australians. That number comes from the report of Brian Burdekin. Many of these children have been forced, through circumstances, to leave their homes because of domestic violence, family breakdowns and a range of other causes. I want to refer to an article in the last December issue of Family Matters. It gave a very detailed analysis of the effect of marital disruption on children. One can only conclude that it does lead to more and more children being forced to live in poverty. One of the other conclusions in the article referred to was that women are more likely to suffer long-term economic consequences of separation and divorce as they are less likely to have paid employment. They are also more likely to have the expense and responsibility of bringing up the children. Children are more often in the custody of the mother. Therefore they too, along with her, suffer the consequence of the lowered income.

Many one parent families live in poverty. The conditions attached to the supporting benefit mean that extra income earned by single parents reduces their benefit to such an extent that it is just not worth trying to make the effort. That is the sort of thing we want to eliminate from the system. We want to make it worth while for families to try to get on and run their lives as they wish. People are forced into either undeclared income or devices of that kind which are not really acceptable or the way to go.

A 1987 study-it has been referred to and reported in Family Matters-showed that 55 per cent of all one parent families are in poverty and that single parent families have the lowest level of disposable income of any family type. One parent families are often housed in poorer areas of a city, in public housing or in private housing, in poor locations such as in industrial areas and near major roads, with limited places for children to play and with bans on pets. They no longer have the opportunity to establish a home because of the interest rates which we all know families have to bear at present. In recent times how many families have been forced to sell their homes and move to other accommodation? Think of the disruption of changing schools, making new friends-all the sorts of things which really make it more difficult for a child to get on in the world and to have the basis of pursuing education.

Today Government members talked about the increased number of people who are completing secondary education and taking up tertiary education. That may be so, but we are talking about the many thousands who are homeless and who are still living in poverty. Our Economic Action Plan deals with that and will deal with it. We are not happy just to leave things as they are. We want to get on with finding solutions to the problems of this country. Many people have been interviewed and there are a myriad of reports. From the information available, there is no doubt that, as a consequence of living in poverty, more young people stay away from school or are truant. More young people are also involved in vandalism or can get caught up with drug abuse, carnal knowledge, stealing, prostitution and driving offences. What hope then do they have of getting on with their lives?

The Government and the people of Australia cannot ignore these facts. The Prime Minister ignored this legacy in 1987 when he made his outrageous claim that no child would live in poverty by 1990. We are not denying that certain things have been done-I say that for the third time. But we want to reach a situation which is markedly better than the one at present. The Labor Party's policies have contributed to making life more difficult for many families-two parents or one parent. They have much less left from their incomes because of the taxation policies of this Government-and think of the effect of inflation, especially on those families in receipt of pensions. Interest rates are so high that many are forced into poverty. People who really believed that they were looking after their families in a proper fashion have not been able to buy clothes and food in the way they have in the past.

The Child Support Agency has been mentioned. I spoke about that last week. The Agency is failing many families because of the way in which it is operating. Parents who are dependent on maintenance to look after their children may wait almost six weeks for payments where there are not any problems or difficulties. The Agency is holding money which it chooses not to pass over for some reason that it decides is relevant. The Child Support Agency is undoubtedly responsible for seeing that some parents who were not paying maintenance before are now paying it. We supported its establishment. However, the Government needs to look very closely at the way it is operating because it, too, is contributing to the number of children who are living in poverty.

The documents read as follows-
(Question No. 1088)
Senator Archer asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 16 June 1989:
(1) Does the beekeeping disease `chalkbrood' exist in New Zealand.
(2) Does it exist in Australia.
(3) Is it regarded as one of the major diseases in the beekeeping industry.
(4) If established in Australia, would it affect the production and the export capacity of the industry; if so, to what extent.
(5) Do quarantine regulations exist to prevent the importation of honey into Australia from countries where the disease exists.
(6) How much honey has been imported from New Zealand during the past five financial years.
(7) Are the present quarantine regulations fully enforced; if not, why not.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Cook

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: (3) It is regarded as a serious exotic disease by the Australian beekeeping industry. Internationally it is not regarded as a major infectious disease of honeybees.

(4) Chalkbrood can lower honey production in weakened and/or badly managed hives by reducing the survival rate of bee larvae. Several factors affect the severity of the disease and an accurate estimate of the likely extent of any production loss if chalkbrood disease established in Australia cannot be made. Production losses within colonies will be greatest at the beginning of an outbreak and will then decrease over time.

(5) Under the Quarantine Act (1908), Proclamation No. 132A, the importation of honeycomb and honey containing honeycomb is prohibited unless the Director of Quarantine is satisfied that its importation is not likely to introduce disease.
(6) According to statistics supplied by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, from 1 July 1984 to 31 June 1989 approximately 626.7 tonnes of honey were imported into Australia from New Zealand.

(7) Procedures for the inspection and clearance of imported bee products are well established and the level of enforcement has proved successful in preventing the introduction of chalkbrood and other exotic diseases into Australia.
Senator Archer asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 27 October 1989:

(1) In relation to the Minister's reply to my Question on Notice No. 1088, (see Senate Hansard of 26 September 1989, page 1363) on what evidence is his comment based that, internationally, chalkbrood is not regarded as a major infectious disease of honeybees.
(2) Does the Minister's comment that chalkbrood can lower production in weakened and/or badly managed hives imply that the disease does not lower production in strong and/or well managed hives.
(3) Is it correct that of 15 samples of honey taken from shop shelves in New Zealand, 12 had chalkbrood spores.
(4) Is there a danger of introducing chalkbrood through importation of honey; if so, why does proclamation no. 132A include bulk honey and honey pre-packs.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Cook

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) Chalkbrood is not considered a major infectious disease of honeybees by the Office International des Eqizooties (OIE), the recognised international reporting body on animal diseases and it is not listed in either of the OIE List A or List B categories. As Australia is free from the disease, however, quarantine restrictions are in place to address the risk of the disease reaching the Australian bee population. The import of bee products is currently under review due to concerns raised over the import of chalkbrood fungus in such products.
(2) Chalkbrood may lower production in strong, well managed hives, but it is usually of less economic importance in such hives.
(3) Informal advice is that a research project performed in New Zealand obtained this result.

(4) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service awaits a final report of the research project performed in New Zealand. On receipt of this report it will make an assessment of the risk of chalkbrood entering Australia in honey and honey pre-packs.

The Waste Watch Committee estimated that something like $200m of unnecessary expenditure had taken place in the construction of this building due, largely, not to the fast-tracking of the project but to the manner of the administration of the fast-tracking of the project and also the requirement that it be completed almost at any cost as long as it was in time for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to get the Queen to open it in the bicentennial year. Following the reports by the Waste Watch Committee, the Parliament House Construction Authority was the subject of an inquiry by the Australian Audit Office. The report of the Audit Office on the Authority's construction project management was then subjected to detailed examination by the Authority itself which presented its response to the Auditor-General's comments. I must say that that report appears to me to be very persuasive. In a general comment at page 83 of its response, the Authority said that the response provides evidence that the efficiency audit report was deficient or in error in many cases and demonstrates that, even where procedural shortfalls were identified, corrective action had generally already been taken.
The Audit Office also states:

. . . the response itself was deficient in not facing issues raised in the audit report. As for procedural shortfalls identified, the audit report disclosed numerous instances where corrective action had not been taken and appeared unlikely to be taken.

As Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, my particular concern was the lack of effective cost controls. It appeared to me that there was a massive gap in that area which was plugged very late indeed. It seems to me that had this gap been plugged, multimillions of dollars of taxpayers' money would have been saved on this project. The Auditor-General appears to share that view. I must say that it is heartening that he should do so. The Auditor-General continues:
Although it was disappointing that the Authority's-
that is, the Parliament House Construction Authority's-

response contained misleading and incorrect material and misrepresentations of ANAO positions . . . it was pleasing that the Authority had moved to implement certain of the ANAO recommendations-this was in contrast to its former position that `nothing of any practical consequence is likely to flow from them' . . . In October 1987 staff of the Authority gave evidence to the Senate Estimates Committee E. The evidence contained errors which ANAO found it necessary to correct. I regret that the level of hostility and argument between the two antagonists in this matter-the Parliament House Construction Authority and the Auditor-General-has reached the stage where one side is clearly saying things that are simply untrue. I also want to say that the Authority seems to be on the wrong track by complaining that the Auditor-General was attacking the concept of the fast-track principle. Obviously, the fast-track method was necessary in order to try to meet the planned opening date. It was simply the administration that was the problem.

It seems silly to me that the Auditor-General should have to reply, item by item, to misstatements made by the Construction Authority, even to the extent of saying what the date was by which it was supposed to be opened. The Auditor-General quotes the statement made by the Prime Minister in 1979 outlining that the building was supposed to be ready for occupancy by Australia Day 1988. Yet the Parliament House Construction Authority had said, `Oh no, it was simply to be opened some time in 1988'. Why are we having this sort of silliness? It does the Parliament House Construction Authority no good at all when one can go back and see exactly what the announcements were. The Auditor-General's report states:

The Authority says that the only `target date' given to the Authority by the Government was in 1978 by the then Prime Minister who said that the Government anticipated the opening of the building would take place in 1988.
That is incorrect. The then Prime Minister, in 1979 in his second reading speech for the Parliament House Construction Authority Bill, said:

As was announced by me in November last the Government has accepted the advice of the Joint Standing Committee and has decided to proceed with the design and construction of a new Parliament House with a view to it being opened on Australia Day, 26 January 1988.

I use that as just one of the many examples of the silly sort of nonsense that has gone on from the Authority, which, frankly, does it no credit in trying to respond to what I thought was a very substantial comment by the Auditor-General.
My general conclusion is this: the Auditor-General was subjected to heavy criticism by the Parliament House Construction Authority. It said:
. . . that the audit report is deficient or in error in many cases and demonstrates that, even where procedural shortfalls are identified, corrective action had generally already been taken.
The Auditor-General's response was:

That is incorrect. The Response provides no evidence that the audit report is deficient or in error in many cases. On the contrary, the Authority's Response has been shown to be deficient in not facing issues raised in the audit report . . .
As for procedural shortfalls by the Authority, the audit report disclosed numerous instances where corrective action had not been taken and appeared unlikely to be taken.
This is another matter where the Authority was incorrect. The Authority says that the Audit Office:
. . . refers to the extraordinary difficulties under which the project was being constructed but does not appear to have taken these into account in focusing its views.
The Audit Office says:

This is incorrect. The Audit Office, when forming its views, took account of the difficult circumstances . . . but made it clear that the Authority should have managed the project better, given its corporate objective to function as an efficient management organisation.
Its last comment is:

The Audit Office accepted that fast track was necessary for the project. The Audit Office's view was that the building might have been completed in less time and at less cost had the Authority's management of the project not suffered from the deficiencies summarised in the audit report.

I conclude on this note because, quite frankly, this is the issue that the Waste Watch Committee was concerned about: that the management of the construction of this building by the Parliament House Construction Authority was such that there was a considerable waste of money. Whether anyone could have done it better is another question altogether. I must say that I think Australians should congratulate the Authority and the project managers for getting this building up in time for the bicentennial. It is the biggest structure ever put up in Australia. It contained massive problems which had to be overcome. They were overcome, but at enormous expense. Surely the Construction Authority would be doing Australia a service if it recognised those areas where, in fact, it could have done better.

I am glad to say that the Construction Authority is now putting into effect what the Auditor-General recommended; that is, putting out a report on what actually happened and what lessons should be learnt from the construction of this building. Let us not pretend-because it will diminish the capacity to learn from mistakes-that mistakes were not made. Also, let the Construction Authority come much cleaner on this matter. I commend the Auditor-General for his perseverance and determination to proceed with this matter. I hope that the lessons to be learnt from the mistakes in the construction of this great public building-even though I think at times it is an appallingly bad parliament building, it is a very great public building which attracts an enormous volume of tourists-are not lost by the Parliament House Construction Authority trying to pretend that the mistakes were not made. This Auditor-General's report underlines the fact that there were mistakes, and we should learn from them.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the Bill before the Senate, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill, is one of potential benefit to many of my constituents-not only Aboriginal Territorians but also other citizens of the Northern Territory. It is designed to give effect to the agreement reached on 6 and 7 September this year between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) so that under this Bill Aboriginal people can receive grants of land, either as something like 150 excisions for living areas from pastoral leases-under Northern Territory law-or by means of grants of 27 individual parcels of land on stock routes or reserves.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that I have been concerned about this matter for some time. My concerns were summed up in the important notice of motion I have had on the Senate's Notice Paper since 15 August. I seek leave to have that prophetic notice incorporated in Hansard. I obtained permission earlier from Senator Tate.
Leave granted.
The notice of motion read as follows:
+173 SENATOR TAMBLING: To move-That the Senate-

(a) notes that, in a Return to Order of the Senate tabled on 24 November 1988 pursuant to Standing order 358, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs purported to provide an explanation for the Minister's failure to move to proclaim certain sections of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Act 1987 which:
(i) declined to provide any timetable for proclamation of the amendments, and
(ii) omitted any reference to section 74 of the Principal Act, an amendment to which is also unproclaimed;

(b) notes with concern that, even though, by circular dated 16 January 1989, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet informed all departments of the Government's acceptance of the Senate's criticism of department's failure to proclaim legislation, amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights Act remain unproclaimed;

(c) is most concerned to note that the failure of the Minister to proclaim amendments to section 50 of the Act is the principal cause of the stalemate in negotiations over excisions of Aboriginal living areas from Northern Territory pastoral properties, with the result that many Aboriginal people continue to live in unacceptable conditions;

(d) views, with concern, therefore, the exchange of correspondence between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) (letter dated 22 August 1989) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory (Mr Perron) (letter dated 23 August 1989) in which the Commonwealth has sought to impose unacceptable conditions on the Northern Territory which:
(i) strike at the essential nature of Territory self-government, and
(ii) can only have the effect of causing further delay in the grant of Aboriginal living areas for those Aboriginal people needing them;

(e) considers that the Northern Territory Government's offer, as set out in the Chief Minister's letter to the Prime Minister dated 11 July 1989, provides a satisfactory basis for settlement of this issue; and
(f) calls on the Government, therefore:
(i) to move forthwith to proclaim the amendments made to the Aboriginal Lands Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 2 years ago, and

(ii) to enter into constructive negotiations with the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association, with a view to facilitating the early grant of living area excisions from pastoral properties in the Northern Territory for Aboriginal people in need of them, on the basis of-

(a) recognition of a `needs' basis for the excision of Aboriginal living areas, as distinct and separate from the criteria for the grant of Aboriginal land under the Aboriginal Lands Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, and
(b) observance by the Commonwealth of the principle of Northern Territory self-government, in particular in relation to land title and the capacity to acquire land for any proper public purpose.
(Notice given 15 August 1989.)
+Notice of motion altered on 29 August 1989 pursuant to Standing Order 109.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Opposition supports this Bill in principle. We shall vote for the second reading. However, for reasons connected with the way the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) does business, we shall be proposing some amendments at the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has application only in the Northern Territory and I remind the Senate that my constituency includes a higher proportion or Aboriginal electors than anywhere else in Australia. Nowhere else is the achievement of proper relations between black and white more central to maintaining community harmony. This Bill represents the culmination of the efforts of the Chief Minister, Marshall Perron, to get that community balance right. I know he has been mindful of the need to achieve a solution to the longstanding problems which Aboriginal people living on pastoral properties face. Because they have no title to land, public funds are not available for improvements to be made. The rabid propaganda of the Minister and the land councils suggest that neither the Northern Territory Government nor the pastoral industry have had any concern for this situation. Yet the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, in his second reading speech in the House of Representatives, recounted the long history of official and pastoral industry efforts to meet Aboriginal needs.

I do not need to retrace that history, which Mr Hand acknowledged went back to the Gibb report-the Committee to Review the situation of Aboriginals on Pastoral Properties in the Northern Territory-recommendations of 1971, 18 years ago. But it is important to look back over the last few years, particularly the period of Federal Labor administration. In 1985, the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, resolved to seek a solution to this long-drawn problem. He obtained the agreement of all parties that, in return for the cessation of all Aboriginal land claims over stock routes and reserves, the pastoralists would facilitate Aboriginal applications for excisions from their leases to provide living areas on those pastoral properties. Minister Holding undertook to amend the principal Act, and indeed he did. He introduced an amending Bill in 1986 and in 1987 the amendment was passed. Among other provisions section 50 was amended to insert subsections 2d and 2e. These would cease all land claims over stock routes and reserves. But then came the sting. These subsections were to come into force only when proclaimed. Since that Bill was passed, however, people have been beavering away in the Labor Party Caucus undermining Mr Holding's promise which had been honourably made and, until then, honourably adhered to. Just who was setting this promise aside? It was the present Minister, Mr Hand, and his mate the member of the House of Representatives for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon-not surprisingly, an employee of the land councils before entering Parliament.

When the new Minister took office in July 1987, he secretly set about negating his predecessor's undertakings. He told no one of his intentions. But as 1988 wore on-not the best of years in Aboriginal affairs-people got to learn that the new Minister was not going to proclaim the amendments. He told no one. However, I asked a few questions about the matter in Estimates Committee E last year. I refer honourable senators to pages e289 to e291 of Estimates Committee E Hansard on 25 October 1988. Suddenly it became clear that there would be no early action-indeed no action ever-to proclaim the amendments.
Senator Macklin picked this up, too, on 24 November last year when the Senate received details of all legislation that had been passed by the Parliament but not proclaimed. Senator Macklin said:
On 1 September I moved a motion which was carried by the Senate on the following day. The motion reads as follows:

That there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before the 25 November 1988, details of all provisions of Acts which come into effect on proclamation and which have not been proclaimed, together with a statement of reasons for their non-proclamation and a timetable for their operation.
Speaking again on 12 April this year, he said:

However, I am certainly not happy with others. The Aboriginal Land Rights Legislation Amendment Act appeared on the old list as well as this one. It was debated quite extensively in this place. In fact, the reasons that are pointed out here for not proclaiming those pieces of legislation are the matter of contention in the debate, which I find absolutely extraordinary. The Government set about refuting it so that it could get this Bill passed and now presumably believes that it was correct in hindsight.

At the time Senator Macklin spoke I was also asking further and detailed questions in Senate Estimates Committee E. The replies to those questions showed clearly that the Minister was running a secret agenda that had absolutely nothing to do with honouring the intentions of the Parliament, still less those of his colleague, Mr Holding. It was then that my other constituents-the pastoral lessees-realised that they were being taken for a ride. I ask for leave of the Senate to table two documents which detail the course of negotiations between the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association Inc. and the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments on this matter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Faced with mounting evidence of the kind detailed in these folders, the cattlemen had had no choice but to withdraw completely from all further negotiations about excisions. The Northern Territory Government also found it necessary to cease any discussions with the Commonwealth. The Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Perron, remained concerned, however, at the conditions in which so many Northern Territory Aboriginal citizens were compelled to live. He took the initiative and sought a meeting with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That meeting took place on 6 and 7 September. The results are set out in the historic memorandum of agreement dated 7 September. Under the terms of the memorandum, the Northern Territory Government agreed to legislate for the grant of excisions, if need be by means of compulsory acquisition. Territory and not Commonwealth law would regulate this process. The Northern Territory Government has now legislated as promised. I refer honourable senators to the Miscellaneous Acts Amendment (Aboriginal Community Living Areas) Bill 1989 of the Northern Territory. The Commonwealth, for its part, agreed that the land rights Act would be amended so that `a small proportion only' of claims of stock route/reserve land would be granted and that further claims over these areas would be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has no quarrel with this deal. I note that the memorandum came about because of Marshall Perron's determination to settle this long-running dispute. I respect his negotiating skill in achieving the outcome he did. But what an indictment the memorandum is of the Minister, Mr Hand, whose secret agenda had to be exploded by his own leader. The memorandum gave the basis for a settlement of the matter. But there was an important further process that then had to be followed. Because the claims over stock routes and reserves were to be granted-that is, `a small proportion only' of them-the selection of areas to be scheduled took on a special importance. The memorandum said the areas would be decided on by the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments. The land councils knew all along what areas would be selected. But pastoral lessees, many of whom had worked and lived for years in the areas concerned, were not informed, let alone consulted about the areas to be scheduled. It is not that they did not ask; they repeatedly approached the Minister and the Prime Minister, seeking some kind of reasonable information about the areas and about the detriment their businesses would suffer. They have had no substantive reply from the Government of any kind. I ask for leave of the Senate to table correspondence between the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association and the Government relating to the matter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will see for themselves the lack of courtesy with which the lessees have been treated and the paucity of information provided, by a supposedly caring Labor Government. On 1 November, I set out in a letter to the Minister a number of practical concerns that the Opposition had about this Bill. Despite many phone calls to his office-over some 41 days-the letter was not replied to until Monday, 11 December. It is dated 8 December, even though I was informed that it was signed on 11 December, and it was casually sent in the rounds and not received until midday on Monday, 11 December. The Minister's responses are derisory. The discourtesy has been shown not just to me, as a senator whose constituents are vitally affected in the matter, but of course, also to those people, whether Aboriginal or not.

SPEECH.PARA: In the committee stage, I shall show just how inadequate some of the responses are and how misleading and contemptuous the Minister has chosen to be. It is apparent, however, that this Minister has extended no more courtesy or consideration to the Northern Territory Government. It was also necessary, therefore, for the Chief Minister to continue with concerned correspondence to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I seek leave to table copies of that important correspondence.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is apparent from Mr Perron's letter of 20 November 1989 that the potential effects of these proposals-once some of the detail became known-had been closely considered by the Northern Territory Government. The detailed comments on the areas to be granted were provided to the Commonwealth, but there is no evidence that these matters then received the careful or specific analysis that they deserved. As the Chief Minister said on 20 November 1989, in a letter to Mr Hand:

SPEECH.PARA: I must express my extreme disappointment at the manner in which you have handled . . . the selection of areas to be scheduled as Aboriginal land.

The issue of most concern to my worried constituents relates to how the areas in schedule 1 to the Bill have been selected and what consideration has been given to the practical effects on pastoral operations. In his second reading speech the Minister purported to give details of `undertakings' given by the Aboriginal claimants which, he said, would demonstrate that pastoral lessees would not suffer any detriment by the grant of land proposed. We have asked for the actual text of those `undertakings' to be provided and so have the cattlemen. As I speak, the Minister and the Prime Minister have just ignored those requests.

At the committee stage, I intend to table a document which seems to include the texts of land council letters setting out the claimants' `undertakings'. It will be clear to the Senate that the Minister's account of those undertakings-for example, who sought them and on the basis of whose advice-and the actual text of the letters are somewhat at variance. It is not that we are unused to this Minister playing fast and loose with the truth in this Parliament. But honourable senators might think by now he would have learned a few lessons.

Last week, on Monday evening, 11 December, I tabled a number of letters to the Minister from individual pastoral lessees who are affected by the proposed land grants. They show that the lessees have not had answers to their legitimate questions. Their concerns have not been addressed. There has been no negotiation with them. They are presented with a fait accompli-like it or lump it. Let me just quote to the Senate from some of the letters the cattlemen have sent to the Minister. The solicitor for Amaroo Station wrote:

Our client uses the Honeymoon area as a trucking point for cattle which includes yards, water and holding paddocks. It would be of significant detriment to our client's pastoral business . . . if the area under claim . . . were granted.
No consultation whatsoever with our client has taken place.
A letter from Deep Well Station stated:
We feel very annoyed, after having had generations on our land, for over 100 years, at having gotten the message the way we did. No consultation, no letter, no prior advice from you at all . . .
The solicitor for Hamilton Down Station wrote:

The scheduling has been proposed without reference to, consultation or consideration of our clients' interests. The result is that our client is to be deprived of resources which will have an adverse effect on his pastoral undertaking.
A letter from Stirling Station stated:
In good faith, traditional owners were given an excision in 1979-one of due to the first excisions to be formalised.
The traditional owners from Wilora community do not want the stock route excised or given away to other Aboriginals.
In this last case, there is even a letter to Mr Hand from the Wilora Aboriginal community. It says:

I wish to advise that the Manager of Stirling Station and myself have been having talks about a living area for my family, Tommy Jungala, and other people who have traditional ties to the area around the Forster Range.
The stock route that is to be given to us is not what we want and will affect the agreement we have with David Bayly, the Manager of Stirling Station.

What was the Minister's reply? Absolutely nothing! So much for all the talk about Aboriginal self-determination. It is okay, until the Aboriginal people try to do something the land councils do not like. Then it is goodbye to self-determination mighty quickly.

There are many such letters. I urge honourable senators to read them. They really show that these people's concerns-my constituents' concerns-are genuine. They really show how their concerns have been utterly disregarded.

The Minister's only response to the cattlemen has been to say that he would discuss their concerns after the Bill has been passed. What is the good of that? By then, the whole thing would be set in concrete. The Minister could look forward to an interesting discussion, but everyone-including the Minister-would be powerless to change anything. How damned idiotic-but typical of Mr Hand's logic.

I remind the Senate that the other half of the 7 September deal has still to be given effect. The grant of living area excisions will require tact, negotiation and goodwill between Aboriginal claimants and pastoral lessees. The Minister's failure to consult the pastoralists must make the next stage harder to achieve and that will be to the cost of Aboriginal people. These are the very people the Minister says he wants to help.

I inform the Senate that the Opposition proposes to move two amendments to the Bill. The first seeks to ensure that the 1987 amendments relating to the removal of stock routes and reserves from land claims do enter into force. Thus, the amendments would make entry into force of the present Bill dependent on proclamation of the 1987 amendments. In my letter of 1 November to the Minister-the letter that took the Minister 41 days to reply to-I asked when those amendments will be proclaimed. I ask Senator Macklin to note his reply. The Minister said:
I am not in a position to tell you the precise date.

I will have more to say about this at the committee stage. The second amendment proposes an administrative law process for the assessment of detriment to holders of land which is in the vicinity of the areas set out in schedule 1, before the area can be granted to Aboriginal claimants. It is really a principle of natural justice.

Neither of these amendments would have been needed if the Minister had dealt frankly and openly in this matter. But we do not trust him. We do not trust him on his record in this matter. More importantly, we do not trust him on his record overall. Let me read to the Senate an extract from the 1989 annual report of the chairman of the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines. It states:

I also have a letter from Mr Hand dated 23 August 1989, some three weeks before the date on the printed Bill. In his letter Mr Hand declines to review the exploration and mining provisions of the Land Rights Act until . . . those provisions of the Act are operating normally.
I am told that Mr Hand's Department was working on amendments to the provisions-the Bill-at the time that he wrote to me to say that it was in-appropriate to review the provisions.

The amendments proposed in the Bill have the potential to impact seriously on the freedom of mineral explorers and miners to go about their work. The proposed amendments are, in several ways, compounding the problems that the Chamber sought to lessen by cooperative approach.

Mr Hand's refusal to undertake a review of the provisions-in his letter to me as President of the Chamber-is therefore doubly surprising. First, it is most likely that the provisions were already under review, as explained above. Second, my request for a review followed a pledge made in June 1987 by the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator the Honourable, Gareth Evans to the Northern Territory Mining Industry that a review would be made two years after that date, viz in June 1989. This commitment has now been dishonoured.

I have given the details of this interchange because it illustrates what I consider to be a very real problem. It seems that trust can no longer be assumed to govern the conduct of business between Mr Hand and this Chamber.

Unless I am missing certain critical pieces of information-and I think not-I am disinclined to do further business with this Minister. I would be likewise disinclined to do business with any company which went about its work in a similar way.

Mr Geoff Sherrington, the President of the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines, was referring to yet another broken promise. This time it is a clear commitment by Senator Evans that, two years after the 1987 `mining regime' amendments to the Land Rights Act had operated, they would be reviewed. I wonder if he asked Senator Evans before he dobbed him in? `But', says Mr Hand, `the land councils are too busy'. The land councils have indeed been busy, spending a record amount on administration; on treaty discussions; on organising the controversial Barunda festival and the stolen ceremonial secrets; on putting down my constituents in east Arnhem Land who want their own land council; and doing the Minister's political footwork on the ill-fated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. They have been busy in fact with everything except their job, and they have been stirring up demands for excisions which they have no legal power to negotiate for.

No doubt the land councils knew all about the amendments to the so-called 1987 mining regime-part iv of the Act. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) who is at the table cannot deny that an earlier draft of this Bill had a whole heap of changes which would have affected mining operations. As Mr Sherrington notes, the last thing the Minister thought of doing was to consult the mining industry. The fact that his Cabinet colleague, Senator Evans, had given a solemn undertaking was, of course, irrelevant.

I take this opportunity to inform the Senate that the Opposition has no difficulty with those amendments remaining in the present Bill which deal with mining matters. I understand that these amendments are likewise acceptable to the Northern Territory Government. I inform the Senate that I intend to pursue the issue of the land councils' financial accountability under the relevant provisions of this Act and in the forums of the Senate. I have already called for a royal commission into this profligacy. The Minister has allowed the secretariats to spend at least $35m since he took office without a thought for the effectiveness of what they spent it on, not to speak of the amount he has let them run up in debts. Consequently, the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account has serious problems and has depreciated capital reserves due to the delinquent actions of the Minister. He has indulged the land councils with his secret agenda for the grant of claims over stock route and reserves and locked everyone else out. Neither the Minister nor the land council secretariats have paid any attention to the damaging effect their thoughtless and arrogant actions have had and must continue to have on community relations in the Northern Territory. For those of us who live in the Territory, no such luxury exists. The aspirations of the Aboriginal people for living area excisions and for some of the land this Bill proposes to grant are legitimate. Equally, the concerns of the cattle industry, which earns $130m export income every year, are legitimate.

It is easy to characterise one group or other of my Northern Territory constituents as those with all right on their side. It is much harder to work for a sensible and sensitive balance in Aboriginal matters as Marshall Perron has always done, and as the Opposition has always sought, in and out of government. The Bill, as we propose it should be amended, will achieve that reasonable balance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that two elements of the speech we have just heard need to be picked up immediately. Senator Tambling implied that in some way Aboriginal people were laying claim to a vast amount of the Northern Territory and/or a section of the Northern Territory which was extremely valuable and extremely likely to interfere with the `legitimate' concerns of the Northern Territory cattlemen. It is important to make clear at the outset that the area of land under claim within the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1989 is 0.17 per cent of the Northern Territory. In a quick calculation, we are talking about one six-hundredth of the area of the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are talking about natural justice, I think it is important to go back in history to somewhat beyond the 1970s and 1980s with which Senator Tambling was dealing and look at the way in which Aboriginal people occupied the Northern Territory for a very much longer period of time before that and, indeed, developed their cultural and religious roots in that Territory in a way which made dispossession from that land a very important element in their survival and the survival of their culture and whole reason for being. If one goes back in time, one recognises that when the Aboriginal people were dispossessed of the land, no question of natural justice or compensation was raised at all; they were simply pushed aside to make way for those who wished to use the land for other purposes. I recognise that that process was based on a legal understanding of terra nullius, as it was in other parts of Australia, and clearly our law does not recognise those Aboriginal claims. However, morally the Aboriginal people have an enormous and natural claim to the whole of the Northern Territory, and that needs to be recognised when we are dealing with this minuscule fraction to which they are now laying claim.

If one moves on from that initial dispossession, one finds that there were periods when Aboriginal people lived on the fringe of cattle properties. For a long time they were able to find part time employment in that industry which, I suppose, provided them with some sort of sustenance and living related to those areas with which they had a natural and historic association. But as the cattle industry developed, particularly after the Second World War, even that level of sustenance and association was taken away from them. As the cattle industry developed other means of transporting and herding cattle and so on, there was less and less need for Aboriginal people to have even that tenuous connection with their traditional areas. So one finds that not only was there a dispossession in the early years but that in recent decades that dispossession, that loss of dignity, of sustenance and of association with their traditional areas, was made worse. If one moves on to 1971, one finds Aboriginal people living across the Territory in absolutely appalling conditions. Even 18 years ago, the report of the Gibb Committee to Review the Situation of Aboriginals on Pastoral Properties in the Northern Territory recommended that there should be excision from pastoral leases to provide community living areas for Aboriginal people close to and associated with those areas with which they had a traditional association.

We move on to 1974 when the Woodward Aboriginal Land Rights Commission again underlined and underscored the need for Aboriginal people to acquire some secure tenure of land in association with those areas with which they had a traditional association. The Whitlam Government of the early 1970s appointed Mr Justice Ward as an Aboriginal Land Commissioner. Mr Justice Ward recommended very much the same thing: the appropriation of small parcels of land so that Aboriginal people could have secure tenure of land and redevelop an association with their traditional roots. After the Whitlam years, one finds that the coalition governments took no action in this matter at all. One then moves to the matters which have been covered by Senator Tambling who, however, did not develop that background. We now have the situation in which real attempts are being made to excise, to provide, small areas-and I emphasise again that it is 0.17 per cent of the whole area of the Northern Territory-of secure land for Aboriginal people to redevelop these associations with their traditional land, to have a place where services can be provided reliably for them-water supplies, sewerage, housing and the like.

When Senator Tambling talked about this proposal to remove this minuscule area of land from the pastoral leases, he talked about natural justice and the way in which the pastoralists were going to be disadvantaged. It is interesting to notice that many of the cattle properties in the Northern Territory have recently changed hands. The value for which they have changed hands, or the sorts of bids that have been made for these properties, has been such as to indicate that, indeed, there has been very little decline in value. Quite the contrary: the property values have been increasing substantially-for instance, in the Ranken River locality and the Soudan locality. These areas are adjacent to five pastoral leases covering approximately 14,000 square kilometres and held by the North Australian Pastoral Company and run as Alexandria Station. The North Australian Pastoral Company has been the subject of a number of takeover bids in recent years. A large volume of its shares have changed hands. A number of other public companies have also been linked with these bids and takeovers, including Elders IXL Ltd and the Australian Agricultural Company. So, indeed, there has been considerable interest in these properties and the purchase of them even while Aboriginal claims to small portions of the land have been in existence.

The Jinka pastoral lease was bought in 1988 for $1.3m. That is hardly a property badly affected by Aboriginal land claims. In the Birdum locality two pastoral leases have changed hands in the past few years. Interestingly, these pastoral leases in the Northern Territory have been subject to considerable speculative exchange by foreign companies; they have been bought and sold. Elsey, formerly owned by an Israeli company, was sold to a Hong Kong company. I wonder whether Senator Tambling is attempting to protect the interests of foreign pastoral owners against the claims of indigenous Aboriginal people. The major interest of the new owner is believed to be not in cattle at all but in the development of the homestead area for tourism.

Turning to the Amaroo pastoral lease, which Senator Tambling mentioned, the claim over Amaroo is approximately one-fortieth of the total area of that pastoral station. Even while those claims were in place, in 1987 Amaroo station was sold for approximately $1.8m. The purchaser of the pastoral lease in that case was the owner of a neighbouring station and therefore a person well aware of the land claims which lay against that station. Even though that person was aware of the land claims-the claims had been in existence for some time-that station still sold for $1.8m. It is hard to argue that the land claims are significantly decreasing the value of this minuscule portion of land to which the Aboriginal people are laying claim.

Moreover, prices paid for pastoral leases have increased sharply in the last three years. Tanami Downs recently sold for $2 1/2m. Two other stations are on the market at the moment for $2.6m and $1.8m. Several stations were transferred on 15 December 1989 for prices believed to be in the region of $1.5m and $2m. Muckaty was sold to a foreign company for tourist development earlier this year for $2m. So the claim which lies behind Senator Tambling's words `for natural justice' I am afraid ring with rather a hollow sound.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spoken like an academic from South Australia.

—The Aboriginal people have never been adequately compensated for the dispossession of their land during the time of white settlement. Surely now is the time for fair and just restitution of a tiny portion of that land to those Aboriginal people, so that they can re-establish links with their traditional land and have secure tenure over a place where they can establish housing and the sorts of services which we in settled areas take for granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for long. It is not necessary to go over the ground of the history of this debate because it has all been said before. I can recall-it seems like ancient history now-delivering a speech years ago in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly on this matter when the Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, was foolish enough to suspend Standing Orders to allow me to have as much time as I wanted to debate the issue. I spoke for four hours and he never made the same offer again. The reason I recall that is that the combined speeches of all the Northern Territory members who spoke in that debate were put together in a single volume and, for some reason-I am not quite sure why-were sent off by Paul Everingham to every Federal member and senator. No doubt they were thrown straight into the nearest rubbish tin. That is simply an indication of just how long this debate has been going on.

SPEECH.PARA: I have risen briefly tonight to indicate that this debate has been going on for long enough. It started 100 years ago in round terms when pastoral properties first became viable enterprises, in a big way, in the Northern Territory. Those cattle stations became viable largely on the basis of the Aboriginal labour that was employed. Although there has been very much discussion about the history-and it is a fairly unhappy history, indeed-of Aboriginal people on those cattle stations, it is worth reflecting on something that Senator Coulter said before the suspension for dinner that was perfectly true. Rightly or wrongly-whether or not one objects to this being said now, I think it deserves to be said and I am glad Senator Coulter said it-it is interesting to reflect on the amount of discussion that we have so far heard about natural justice in respect of cattle stations because there was not a lot of natural justice in the way Aboriginal people were treated during the history of possession of Aboriginal land by pastoralists in the Northern Territory.

I will include one other little piece of history, and one only, in this debate which relates to the way Aboriginal people were treated on cattle stations. People can make their own assessments as to the justice or otherwise that has been meted out to them since. I have a short extract from an extremely handy publication called Equal Wages for Aborigines by Dr Frank Stevens. This is an academic synopsis of the very famous wages case involving Aboriginal pastoral workers in the Northern Territory. It is interesting to note that when the pre-eminent pastoralist of the Northern Territory, Lord Vestey, was running into considerable problems because of declining numbers of Aboriginal workers on his cattle station in the Northern Territory, he sought the assistance of Dr Berndt. Much to Dr Berndt's discomfiture, he discovered that the fact that Lord Vestey was seeking his assistance had nothing to do with the new enlightened attitude on the part of Vestey towards his Aboriginal employees but that he simply wanted Berndt to advise him on what anthropological information would be handy in order to recruit more Aboriginal stockmen for his cattle stations.

When he did so Berndt made a number of rather radical suggestions to the management of Vestey's as to how perhaps the company could encourage more Aboriginal people to put themselves forward to work for 14 hours a day, which was the average, seven days a week, which were the working conditions on cattle stations, and probably still are. Berndt put forward the extremely radical proposal that in order to attract more Aboriginal people to work these hours Vestey's may consider the prospect of actually paying them for working. The response was very interesting. It is outlined by Dr Frank Stevens in his publication Equal Wages for Aborigines:

Over a period of time Berndt made a series of suggestions to the management concerning the improvement of conditions for the Aborigines and the introduction of a small cash wage. The company was at first incensed by some of his suggestions and they endeavoured to manipulate the administration into carrying out the improvements.
The administration is the administration of the Northern Territory Government. I continue:

A recommendation for the introduction of cash rewards was flatly rejected with the terse reply: `We are opposed to the payment of wages to natives, and consider that there has been enough trouble with wage systems. Money seems to be the root of all evil'.
Coming from Vestey's, I thought that was pretty cute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never paid taxes in the UK.

—No. As Senator Tate has interjected quite accurately, one of the things Vestey's was famous for in its operations in Australia was that, despite the millions of pounds, as the currency then was, that it extracted from this country, it was proud of the fact that it never paid taxes. Berndt went on to comment on the company's rejection of his radical suggestion that Aboriginal people might actually be given a little bit of money for their work. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Here were the same tendencies that marked the control of `white' workers in Europe in the nineteenth century before the `sweating' of labour for quick profits began to give way to more enlightened tactics. In both cases, there were assumptions that workers were plentiful, that it was unnecessary to worry about the future supply.

Vestys is anxious to retain the status quo-at least as long as they can manage it. They resent any interference with `their natives' and look on Government regulations as unjust and annoying `red tape' to be circumvented wherever possible. Some, on these stations, as on others, actively dislike the Aborigines, and express indifference or positive pleasure at the thought of their ultimate extinction.

Unfortunately for the people of those days, Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory succeeded in surviving with their culture and lives to some extent intact. Here we are today, a hundred years on, debating the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill.

Senator Coulter also said accurately that in respect of the areas provided for scheduling in this Bill we are debating 0.176 per cent of the Northern Territory's land mass. It is interesting that many people in government in the Northern Territory-I recall quite well when this happened-can embrace with great pleasure and public enthusiasm the prospect of a Northern Territory pastoral property, thousands and thousands of square kilometres of it, being acquired by an absentee Los Angeles dentist but at the same time find it extraordinarily difficult to come to terms with people who have been indigenous to this country for thousands of years occupying the same land.

Another statistic which is very relevant to this debate and to the amendments that have been brought before this chamber by Senator Tambling is that only 26 per cent of all of the land that is legally available for claim by Aboriginals-that is, stock routes which are claimable-is the subject of scheduling under this Bill. On balance I do not think that is a bad deal for all concerned.

I would be reluctant to see this debate prolonged any further. Obviously, as is always the case with these debates, neither side will get a reasonable percentage of what they want. Certainly, Aboriginal people do not think that they are getting a magnificent deal from this legislation. They have some validity to feel that way. Nevertheless, at long last, unbelievable as it may seem, we are within touching distance of achieving a resolution of this matter.

The reason that I have risen tonight is that I am very conscious of the fact that this week we are spending the last days of the parliamentary decade in this chamber. The 1980s are a few days away, in parliamentary terms, from being finished. It would be a major disgrace and a major scandal for this Parliament if, after 100 years of this problem, and if after at least 20 years in contemporary history of no resolution of this problem on behalf of what are arguably-in my view, beyond argument-the most deprived citizens in this country, we finished this decade of the 1980s in this Parliament without having resolved it. I urge all members of the Senate to approach the balance of this debate in that spirit and let us have done with it. Let us have this legislation processed. Let us have it go back to the House of Representatives to be finalised. Let us have it assented to by the Governor-General. Let us at long last in the 1990s get on with the job of actually providing titles and giving people some decent living conditions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the eloquence of Senator Collins, drawing on very extensive knowledge, I feel that my contribution can only be rather threadbare. It is an historic moment, as Senator Collins has suggested, because we are within touch, or perhaps, to use a more Australian expression, within cooee of passing the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1989. It needs to be emphasised that not only is it a matter for this chamber to come to a resolution tonight, as I understand it will, for the House of Representatives to concur and for the Governor-General to signify his assent-we are the national Parliament engaged in this great enterprise on behalf of the most disadvantaged people in the Australian community-but I think it is only fair to say that this is a joint enterprise with the Government and the Parliament of the Northern Territory. The success of this particular project will depend on the continuing goodwill, no doubt, of those who have been associated with the very extensive and arduous negotiations which have reached their high point over the last several months.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory are to be commended for the agreement which they reached at that high and exalted level, taking political responsibility for the compromise, as Senator Collins quite properly calls it, which is embodied in this legislation and in complementary legislation by the Northern Territory Assembly, and whilst they take the political credit, I think one has to say that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, deserves much of the political credit for his continual concern for a resolution of this issue. I believe that, if it had not been for his persistence in the face of many hurdles being raised, we would not be at the stage that both governments and both parliaments are very happily at, at the end of 1989.

If Senator Tambling's caricature of Mr Gerry Hand has even a touch of being correct, it is a misinterpretation of the passionate concern that Mr Hand has had for the betterment of the living conditions of those Aboriginals living in the pastoral areas of the Northern Territory, his passion that they should have such a secure title to land that they can enjoy that feeling of security and that bonding with the land, which I think we can in a measure understand but which has such a depth to it in the relationship of Aboriginal people to these areas of land. The obtaining of justice for these Aboriginal families, groups and individuals will be a significant breakthrough.

When one considers the history of Aboriginal people in relation to the pastoral proprietors, as outlined in part by Senator Collins, one can see how the Australian community, as represented by both its governments in parliaments, has reached a much more mature understanding of the proper way in which those Aboriginal communities ought to be able to enjoy some secure title to their land. That struggle, which has appeared so fruitless and with which people have persevered against great odds over the last decade or so, is now reaching its fulfilment. I believe that it is to the credit of all those concerned that we have reached this necessary prelude-and it is only a prelude in my view-to the improvement in the living conditions of the Aboriginals concerned. I believe that secure title will enable the provision of those facilities in those areas and give Aboriginal communities those minimum living conditions which are so essential for their health and well-being. In particular such living conditions are essential for the health and well-being of the babies and youngsters who will be born into, be nurtured in and live part of their lives in these areas.

This is indeed a very significant moment and, despite what Senator Tambling said, I believe that it is the result of extensive and considerable consultation. It is certainly the result of extensive, considerable and long-running discussions-one might say that is a slightly different word-but I believe that `consultation' is certainly the correct term to use in relation to consultations with the Northern Territory Government. The working party formed in 1987 was an important part in this process of consultation. It is certainly the case that, after the signing of the memorandum of agreement by the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister, consultation continued with the Northern Territory at officer level.

I believe that those consultations have been going on and will go on because it is quite clearly part of the scheme of this Bill that regulations can be made which will help deal with misgivings or difficulties that might arise in the way in which the boundaries are scheduled. Of course, once the grant is made of the interest in land that will be the end of it and the process has to stop; there has to be a reasonable coming to an end of the consultations. But there is no intention in the passage of this legislation tonight, or through the Parliament in the next few days, for there to be some sort of cutting off of the consultation, either with the Northern Territory Government as an elected representative group representing all Territorians, or with the pastoralists, perhaps represented most notably by the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association Inc. Those consultations can continue; the Bill specifically envisages that those consultations will continue; and I am quite sure that, if any case can be made out that there is some unreasonable interference with cattle operations on pastoral properties as a result of the way in which a boundary is drawn, that can be dealt with, and I am sure an undertaking supplementary to the drawing of boundaries can also ensure that the legitimate interests of the pastoralists are accommodated.

But the primary interest to be accommodated at this historic moment, as Senator Collins puts it and I am sure it is supported by all honourable senators, is the future of our Aboriginal brothers and sisters in the Territory. I believe that this is a moment in which the whole Parliament can take great pleasure. We have a justifiable pride in our democracy, in our ability to take a contentious issue and, even if it takes longer than many would hope, in the end we resolve it in a relatively peaceful, non-violent manner by the coming together of the heads of our respective elected governments. This legislation flows from those agreements. I certainly commend the second reading of this Bill to the chamber and I hope that the Senate will give the rest of the proceedings a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
