The long history of the negotiations in that period since 1985 was very well set out in the two comprehensive folders that I tabled during the second reading debate.

In the saga of seeking to resolve this matter, and I accept most of the comments made by Senator Tate in his closing address, the issue needs to be addressed very profoundly and in a very historical context. As will be noted, the Opposition supported the second reading of this Bill and in fact it supports the major principles and the memorandum, that was reached between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Our major problems relate to technical and administrative matters. The Committee will note that the three amendments that I will be moving this evening are all of that nature. One of the questions I put to him was this:

The 6/7 September Memorandum says that, upon enactment of the scheduling legislation the Commonwealth will then proclaim the June 1987 amendments. Page 7 of your Second Reading Speech says, after referring to the `granting of certain parts of existing land claims' that the 1987 amendments will be proclaimed `at the same time'. It is important, I acknowledge, that the proclamation of section 50 of the land rights Act proceed as quickly as possible, limiting the right to claim stock routes and reserves. With this legislation we are trying to ensure that the will of the Parliament is carried into effect fully by the granting of certain interests in land. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The amendment we are dealing with involves an interesting principle. Schedule 1 lists all of the properties which, when the Act began in 1978, were automatically capable of being granted to Aboriginal land trusts, once formed. No claims assessment process by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner was needed. Schedule 1 to the present Bill sets out the list of areas to be inserted in parts 2 and 3 of schedule 1 of the principal Act; thus they are automatically capable of grant to land trusts, once formed. The only other time that this procedure was followed was when Uluru-Ayers Rock-was transferred and, in that case, the deal involved a lease back to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. In the case of the present Bill 2,312 square kilometres or, as was mentioned earlier, 26 per cent of the ambit claims, are to be transferred. That is not a bad outcome for the land councils and the claimants. This clause will allow the Minister to vary the descriptions of land by regulation up to the time of their actual grant to a land trust. That the Government saw a need for such provisions shows just how hastily the whole schedule has been drawn up. As a matter of law the Minister could vary the areas by increasing or decreasing the areas in the Bill quite substantially. In his second reading speech the Minister, Mr Hand, said:
The provision is not intended to permit major changes to the area of land to be granted and the power will not be available until the land has actually been granted.

That is in Hansard, page 2157. That is all very well but as I have said earlier, how can the Minister be trusted? If we look at clause 4 of the Bill, the power to change would be available for two years during which time a lot of bargaining could go on. I refer again to the letter I wrote to the Minister on 1 November in which I asked whether he would be prepared to give an assurance that the modification would be limited only. His reply was to decline to give such an assurance.

The Opposition's amendment proposes a different approach. We propose a new section 77c. The section would lay down a procedure which would require the Minister to make sure, in relation to each area listed in parts 2 and 3 of schedule 1, that a person with an interest in land in the vicinity of the land to be granted had been given an opportunity to have his representations considered as to any detriment that person might suffer and for the Minister to consider and respond to such representations. The land in parts 2 and 3 of schedule 1 was listed without any consultation with the affected pastoralists. I tabled copies of these letters to Mr Hand on Monday, 11 December which show this to be the case. Nobody knows how the areas were decided on. The Minister has reported to Parliament that the Aboriginal claimants have made undertakings about access to water and similar matters for pastoralists in the vicinity. The Minister said:

The Government has taken steps to ensure that pastoral operations are not unreasonably interfered with by the granting of these areas of land. Where appropriate I have sought relevant undertakings from the Aboriginal claimants for the continued use of station roads, bores or infrastructure by the pastoral lessees. In some instances, the areas have been amended to exclude access corridors or areas of particular concern to pastoralists or the Northern Territory.
Before I go into the detail of the undertakings that have been given, or the land which has been given up by claimants, I want to make two general observations.

Firstly, these undertakings are really about sharing the country and the resources. In acceding to my requests for undertakings, the Aboriginal claimants have again demonstrated a willingness to share their land with pastoral operations. This continued willingness to share, and to compromise, is a real tribute to the Aboriginal people.

Secondly, where possible, every effort has been made to resolve issues of particular concern raised with me by the Northern Territory by a letter of 25 September, 1989. However, I wish to express my disappointment that the Northern Territory has not continued to inform me or officers of my Department of its concerns in relation to the areas to be scheduled as consultations have progressed. While Aboriginal people have remained willing to compromise, the Northern Territory has again shown a disinclination to consider realistically how detriment issues might be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1 November I have been trying to get answers to a number of questions about the areas to be scheduled and what the Minister did in relation to detriment. I asked the Minister for copies of the actual texts of the undertakings. He has declined to provide them saying that they will be discussed with the lessees after the areas have been scheduled. Of course, it would be too late then to do more than make minor adjustments to the boundaries. I am forced to draw the conclusion that the Parliament, once again, is not to be told all that it is entitled to know.

SPEECH.PARA: Letters to the Minister from many pastoral lessees explaining in detail how their livelihoods will be affected were tabled in the Senate last Monday evening, 11 December; yet, we have seen no sign of concern nor willingness to consult by the Minister. All he has said is that he will talk to the pastoralists after the Bill goes through. What is the use of that? The Opposition is proposing a procedure under which the Minister will be required to consider representations as to detriment before the areas in the schedule can be granted. None of this would have been necessary had the Minister talked frankly with the pastoral lessees before settling the schedule. But he just ignored their requests, quite reasonable in the circumstances, and settled what went into the schedule in some kind of deal with the land councils.

Our amendment seeks to give those adversely affected some belated and limited rights to put their cases and to have their concerns as citizens determined in accordance with the principles of natural justice. The question that remains is: who will pay for the fencing, the rebuilding of stockyards and the like, the new bores and the related works which these grants will necessitate? Will the Minister who is sitting at the table, Senator Tate, give an answer to those matters? The limited guarantees proposed in our amendment would not be needed had the land claims made over stock routes and reserves been subject to consideration by the Land Commissioner in the usual way. Then the issue of detriment would have received proper attention. The Minister has paid no attention to detriment issues. Instead he has had some kind of secret talks with the land councils and has then given Parliament a partially true account of what was agreed. The record shows that. As the automatic scheduling process bypasses the usual checks and balances, that is the very reason why our amendment is needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with it?
—It has got this to do with it. This has been a tortuous process which has been taken most of this decade to achieve.
—So?

—I must say at this point in respect of that interjection that it is very easy for Senator Alston to sit back and say, `So'. He is totally unaffected by this debate. Senator Alston has the hide to come in here during the committee stage and reel off references to things such as extinguishing people's rights and denying people natural justice. For Senator Alston's information, I will tell him, in terms of extinguishing people's rights and denying people natural justice, how I became politicised. I went to the Northern Territory when I was 20 years of age, wet behind the ears and off the land. I am still a very conservative person, a person with a predisposition to support the pastoral side of an argument. During my first year in the Northern Territory-I noted with some interest just a few months ago that I seem to have something in common with the Opposition's Leader in terms of the story he was telling about his early life-I was forced as a 20-year-old extension officer for the Department of Agriculture to work on a Northern Territory cattle station. We are not talking about 100 years ago now; we are talking about 20-odd years ago, in a place near Katherine. The station was run by a white station manager and Aboriginal staff, stockmen, who lived in a camp near the homestead.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a 20-year-old from a fairly strict background, I might add, in terms of the religious instruction that I had belted into me. I was a person who in those days would not, as the Australian expression goes, say `shit' for sixpence. I shared that homestead with a white station manager and, to my horror, discovered on my second day that it was his practice to cohabit, about 10 feet away from where I had to sleep in a single-room bough shed, which is what the homestead was, with a different girl from the Aboriginal camp every night, who had no choice in the matter. We were marooned from civilised society. I was stuck out there for six weeks with no way of getting back to town. He was regularly and routinely sleeping with Aboriginal kids who, had they been white kids living in town, would have been in primary school. My objections to that practice fell on deaf ears. I also witnessed the same bloke knock unconscious an Aboriginal stockman with a shifting spanner because this bloke happened to do the wrong thing while he was changing the wheel of a tractor. I was there when it happened. It was a vicious physical assault. Had it happened anywhere else, and to someone who was white, it would have got him two or three years in prison.

This same person was responsible for something even more horrendous. He was an alcoholic, as so many of these people were in the Northern Territory in those days. He used to go into town regularly on a binge. In fact-and I saw this with my own eyes-it was the practice for the station overseers, who were very badly paid by any standards in those days-almost as badly paid as the Aboriginal people who were employed, which I guess resulted in the type of person who worked in this situation-to get paid a lot of their wages in booze, rum in fact. In those days we called it crinkly-Beenleigh in corrugated bottles. He chose to be paid in that way.

Every six months or so, perhaps every 12 months, he would go into town on a bender. On one renowned occasion he went into town on a bender to get on the booze for three or four days and he took with him a young Aboriginal girl. He tied her up in the back of his truck so that she could not get away. He left the truck parked under a tree outside Katherine. He then got on the booze and forgot about her for a couple of days. When it was time for him to go back to the station, she had been lying in the back of the truck, tied up, with no food or water, for 48 hours, and it was the dry season. He went back to the station in this truck. On the way back, he stopped the truck when he decided he needed a bit of sexual relief. Because of his drunken condition, the girl was able to get away from him. But she did not make it back to the station; she died of thirst on the way back. It was only a week or so later, when the Aboriginal people who lived in the camp on that station worked up enough courage to report it, that a search party was put out for that girl and they found her dead body within a day's march of the station.

So it is with some degree of frustration that I speak in this debate. Senator Alston says that he has come late to this debate. So what? I am sitting here tonight in the dying moments of the decade of the eighties listening to Senator Alston, who knows nothing of these issues, talking about extinguishing people's rights and denying people natural justice. Senator Tate has said quite correctly that this is a political decision that has rightly been made to a political problem. It comes at the end of a long and tortuous process of negotiation which, as I said before, has occupied the major part of this decade. One would hope that we can go into the 1990s trying to put right some of these wrongs that are not just textbook academic matters that have been written up in books by Berndt, Stanner or others; they are things I have seen with my own eyes. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Political Parties: Registration of Names-ANZUS Treaty-New South Wales Politics

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak further to a matter that I spoke on in an adjournment debate in the Senate about 10 days ago concerning the registration of political party names and the procedures that are available under the Electoral Act. An example which has occurred recently lends weight to the need for the Act to be amended.

SPEECH.PARA: I have discovered that it is possible for people who belong to a political party to change that party's name without reference to its membership, without having to prove to the Australian Electoral Commission that it has 500 registered members. The example I mentioned in the Senate recently concerned the Democratic Socialist Party being renamed; it changed its name to the Socialist Workers Party. I have since discovered that, in accordance with the Act, that party was not required to prove to the Australian Electoral Commission that it had 500 members. If a new party were being formed, it would be required to prove that it had 500 members. The Democratic Socialist Party does not have to prove that because it is only changing its name. When the original party was first registered, in 1984, the Act did not even require production of proof of 500 members. I believe that is a deficiency because it means that a very small group of people who register a name can keep that name basically for all time despite the fact that it may never run a candidate at an election and that it may no longer support the aims of the party it originally registered. This is a considerable weakness in the Act. I have explained how I thought that it was an absolute fraud for the Socialist Workers Party to rename itself the Democratic Socialist Party because as far as I am concerned there is a world of difference between the ideologies of what those names stand for.

I have also discovered that under the Act when a party changes its name it is not required to consult its membership. Those people who registered the Socialist Workers Party about four or five years ago changed the name without reference to the membership-if it had a membership. That is another deficiency. I imagine that if any of the major political parties represented in this chamber-the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats-attempted to change their name without consulting the broad range of their membership there would be a fair riot and disagreement amongst the membership were it to be done by only two or three people. As I understand it, that is what the Socialist Workers Party has done recently. It claims that it had some consultation but the Party was not required to prove that to the Australian Electoral Commission. That is a weakness in the Act.

A further weakness which should be looked at concerns the fact that a party, once registered, can keep that name for all time. It should be a requirement of the Act that, at least once every five or seven years, the Electoral Commission should conduct an audit of all parties registered with it, particularly those defined as non-parliamentary parties, so that there can be a check of the membership list. I further understand that under the present Act the `membership list' for those registering for the first time is pretty loosely defined. In fact, it appears that just getting people to sign a petition can be taken as evidence that they are members or supporters of a particular party. There is no requirement for them to be issued with membership tickets or for non-parliamentary parties to keep records. I believe that, again, is a deficiency.

I also discovered that one can actually be a member of a political party that is already registered as a non-parliamentary party, and one's membership can be counted when another new party is being registered. That is a loophole which is far too wide and makes a joke of the registration provisions.

These are areas that the Parliament-particularly, the Government-ought to have a look at. I hope that all political parties represented here, irrespective of our different ideological positions, realise that there is a need for these areas to be tightened up. As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I hope that some time in the near future we can conduct a brief inquiry into this section of the Act and make recommendations to Parliament to tighten up the procedures, if they are not already tidied up. I understand there is a Bill before Parliament at the moment, which may be debated later this week, containing amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. These matters could be looked at then.

An example of what caused me to further raise this matter is the extraordinary circumstances which recently occurred in New South Wales concerning the selection of candidates for the so-called Green Alliance. I must confess that I come from South Australia so the ins and outs of New South Wales party politics may have escaped me from time to time. What happened with the Green Alliance is an extraordinary procedure for any political party which tries to establish itself with any credibility in the community.

I have since discovered that the Green Alliance includes not only people who have had the name `Greens' registered from 1984-which was a take off of the German Green Party-but also people who were registered initially as the Socialist Workers Party, whose name has now been changed to the Democratic Socialist Party, and those who were registered as the Aboriginal Land Councils of New South Wales. They have registered individually, but have put together what is called a Green Alliance ticket. How they arrived at this ticket gives weight to the matters which are of concern.
I have obtained a copy of a brief statement which the Green Alliance put out earlier this month explaining how it was selecting its candidates. It states:
Sunday, December 10, Sydney University, Manning House, 9.30 am, the Green Alliance* Senate team for NSW will be chosen.

This is extraordinary to anybody who has had any involvement in party organisation, particularly someone like myself who has spent many years as a full time party official in South Australia. The document states:
The selection conference will be an open, public event held in Sydney & networked throughout Pegasus.

I have subsequently found out that Pegasus is actually a computer system. Apparently, the selection processes for the New South Wales Green Alliance means that one can turn up at an open, public meeting-one does not have to be a member of the Alliance in any way, but could claim to be interested in environmental issues in the broadest possible sense-and vote to select candidates. But, if one could not make it to the meeting, as I think this statement makes clear, one could participate by using one's computer terminal in the Pegasus system to indicate which of the candidates one wishes to support. There was a list of about 13 candidates standing for preselection for a position on a team of six. It said that the meeting would:

. . . also discuss policy, accountability and the question of rotation. If you are green you can attend the conference, or tune into Pegasus via, gpn: green-forum conference and vote in this selection or nominate for a position on the team.

I know we all believe at times that existing parties may get a little bureaucratic in all our procedures, but I do not think any of us believe that a political party should have such a system open to what I would call perverting the political process for anybody who chose to turn up who may be completely anti-environmental in their policies and could participate. It says further:

The Green Alliance was formed at the 9-10 September 89 conference by 250 people from all over New South Wales and is open to all individuals, groups and organisations who subscribe to the four basic principles of the German Greens: an ecologically sustainable economy; grassroots democracy; social and economic equality; and disarmament and non-violence.
I suppose basically we would all say that those are motherhood positions which everybody in the community would believe are quite reasonable. They then selected, out of those 13 people, six--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got much longer to go?

—I have about three minutes. They then selected their candidates and, at best, about 150 people voted. We do not know whether they voted by computer or voted by turning up at the public meeting. The candidate who topped the ticket got a grand sum total of 35 votes and the person who came sixth got eight votes. The person who topped the ticket admits to being a member of the Democratic Socialist Party, formerly the Socialist Workers Party, yet is seeking to lead, and be selected to lead, the Green Alliance. Again, I believe that indicates a weakness in the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that some of the descriptions of people who sought preselection do raise one's eyebrows about how serious they are. For example, there was a Brenda Lloyd, who is described as:

Formerly of the World Wildlife Fund and the Green Party in the UK, practical Green who has installed a composting toilet in her eastern suburbs home and begun a campaign against the Water Board's $80 `environment' levy.

I know that people often describe Australian politics in unkind words, but I have never heard of a candidate claiming as a basis for his selection that he has a particular type of toilet installed in his home. We also have people such as Larry O'Brien, who is described as:
Manager, qualified in education and communications, an inner-city green.
Also, we have Julien Droulers, described as:
Taxi driver with a long established interest in independent political representation, particularly interested in gaining corporate support for green politics.

All in all, it is a range of people. Whatever we may think of their particular standing, what they have done is open to an accusation of abuse of the system of party registration. It is clear that they do not have anywhere near 500 party members but at the best they could get about 150 people to vote; and to get 150 people to vote they said that anybody could turn up at the public meeting, or, if they could not turn up, they could tune in via their computer terminal. I do not believe that the Electoral Act, which was passed in 1984 and subsequently amended, should allow this sort of process to go on. I believe that when the people of New South Wales come to vote at the next Federal election, and particularly for the Senate, they ought to have a very close look at the composition of the so-called Green Senate Team and, in particular, the Parliament should have a close look at the Act to ensure that this sort of procedure is not allowed; otherwise it will bring the operation of the Electoral Act into disrepute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to address a matter which has been of great concern to me since I came into this Parliament in 1985-the question of our relationship with the United States in the ANZUS alliance. The recent changes in Europe, which seem destined to make both the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) and the Warsaw Pact redundant, have implications for Australia and the ANZUS alliance. As the Cold War is proclaimed to be dead and the threat of confrontation in Europe recedes, both the United States (US) and the Soviet Union are considering massive cuts in their military expenditure. The Europeans are looking at new defence options. Finlandisation is no longer a dirty word and concepts such as non-offensive defence and even social defence are being discussed. The military realise that they can no longer automatically order their next expensive generation of toys and there is an ongoing debate over where the cutbacks will have to be.

SPEECH.PARA: United States and European journals are giving wide coverage to this debate and economists are hopeful that peace will bring great economic benefits to the United States which has been crippled by the doubling of military expenditure under the Reagan Administration. Sadly, none of this is reflected in Australia. Here we watch the defence budget slowly continuing to grow while the Government tries to double military exports in order to pay for military imports costing us over $1 billion per year and contributing significantly to the balance of payments deficit.

Both the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) continue to pledge allegiance to ANZUS. Australia continues to side with the conservative Bush Administration in Washington rather than a Labour government across the Tasman which had the foresight to see the irrelevance of nuclear weapons in the South Pacific and dared to challenge its alliance partners. The Cold War is over; ANZUS is redundant, yet few politicians appear willing to get up and say so. There is great interest in the situation in Europe, but no lessons seem to be drawn for the Pacific.

It is worth considering how ANZUS began. The central rationale for the creation of the Pacific Pact, as it was first known, was a direct result of unease in Canberra and Wellington over the future potential threat posed to them by a resurgent and rearmed Japan. Some American officials considered that Australia and New Zealand were hysterical in their concern of a repeat of a future Asian threat to their security. Their defence needs stipulated that any threat to them should be met as far away as possible and within a collective security arrangement. In other words, it was a continuation of the forward defence strategy under United States auspices rather than under the British.

When the concept was first floated, the United States showed little interest. However, the Truman Administration had committed itself to a policy of military containment of the Soviet Union by 1947, culminating in the formation of NATO in April 1949. The idea of containment spread quickly from Europe to Asia as the doctrine assumed the much wider purpose of resisting any communist or revolutionary movement likely to challenge the United States concept of world order. In the meantime allied wartime links were further developed. Intelligence cooperation was formalised in 1947 with the United Kingdom-United States of America Agreement--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 406. I think in circumstances such as this at the end of a long session that if the senator has a prepared document it might be better to seek leave to table it and we could all look at it perhaps in the New Year. If she does insist in continuing in this light, perhaps she might at least do us the courtesy of looking up occasionally.
—I am loath to use that standing order because of the use of copious notes, but I will watch Senator Vallentine very carefully and, if I believe that she is reading her speech, I will stop her.

—Thank you, Mr President. As I was saying, the wartime links were further developed and the concept of containment spread rapidly from Europe to Asia. When the United Kingdom-United States of America Agreement was signed in 1947, the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), with the British intelligence agencies, helped to set up the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Australian Secret Intelligence Service in 1949 and 1950.

SPEECH.PARA: United States interest in the Pacific Pact grew following the Chinese revolution in October 1949 and the outbreak of the Korean War in the following year. Unable to construct in the Pacific a single strategic system comparable to NATO, the United States began to explore the possibility of a series of separate military arrangements. The intention was to create a loose but effective anti-communist coalition centred on the United States but comprising the countries situated on the rim of the Western Pacific. In the end, treaties were concluded with the Philippines, Australia and New Zealand, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, followed by the Manila Pact, better known as SEATO, or the South East Asia Treaty Organisation. Curiously, a poll in 1951 showed that 74 per cent of those asked in the sample had read or heard of the new defence pact. But in 1982, only 65 per cent of a sample of 2,000 Australians had heard of ANZUS, and of that percentage only 41 per cent knew that the United States was a member.

There was little public fanfare in the early days of ANZUS. This was partly due to the creation of the SEATO in 1954 and the prominence it played in the diplomatic affairs of South East Asia until the late 1960s. However, realising that the ANZUS treaty was particularly loose and did not guarantee United States intervention in support of Australia should a crisis arise, Prime Minister Menzies and the then Foreign Minister, Lord Casey, invited the United States to consider the option of putting military bases on Australian soil knowing that, if the United States had a military presence or bases which were significant to it on Australian soil, it would be much more likely to get involved in rescuing Australia in a time of crisis.

The first permanent American installation in Australia was the seismic station at Alice Springs. This agreement was signed in 1955, but the true nature of the installation was not disclosed until February 1973. So there is a huge time gap between the installation first being assigned and that knowledge being made publicly available. As Des Ball, the head of defence and strategic studies at the Australian National University, has written:

The secrecy, evasion and deception associated with the American installations in Australia seems to be intrinsic to them; it goes back to their origins during World War II and has characterised all subsequent developments.

The most obsessive secrecy has been over Pine Gap and Nurrungar. The then Minister for Defence in 1969 emphasised military reasons for secrecy over Nurrungar in 1969 but Prime Minister Gorton talked wholly in terms of Pine Gap's enhancing the strength of the ANZUS alliance as the Hansard records of the day so clearly show. The Labor Government which followed was hardly any better. It continued to relate the bases to ANZUS. Yet the ANZUS document itself does not say anything about the installation of bases on Australian soil, nor about the visits of nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered warships to our ports.

The myths of ANZUS and the dependency relationship are so powerful that John Gorton, William McMahon and Gough Whitlam all admitted that they were ignorant of major aspects of the operations of the satellite ground stations in central Australia. It seemed that they neither knew nor cared about what went on at Pine Gap in particular, until Gough Whitlam became concerned-and we know what happened to him in 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —And then they were changed to `joint facilities'.

—Yes, they were then called `joint facilities' which is a misnomer and a euphemism. Australians were up against governments which did not believe in consulting them on issues of defence and national security, nor were they in turn willing to ask questions of the United States, even supposing they would be given an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: When Robert Menzies announced the establishment of the North West Cape facility in my home State of Western Australia, he said it was to provide radio communications but he never mentioned submarines, let alone missile-carrying submarines. Later, in 1973, the United States used the North West Cape to communicate the general alert to its convention on nuclear forces in the region at the time of the Yom Kippur war in the Middle East but did not inform the Australian Government. Five years later Jim Killen as Minister for Defence was caught out when the Australian Financial Review carried a story about a new satellite ground station at North West Cape, but the relevant US authorities had never told him that the contract had been let. There was no attempt at consultation; he was not even told.

Using the ANZUS myth, the US has taken Australia for granted. Australian governments either have not cared or have been too scared to protest at their humiliation at being kept in the dark by our so-called wise and powerful friend. The TRANET station at Smithfield in South Australia was operating for 12 years before the Defence Department thought to ask the Pentagon what the strategic role of the station was with respect to the navigation of fleet ballistic missile submarines. It is, therefore, not surprising that so few Australians can identify these bases on our soil and know even less about what they do. In fact, we do not know how many of these bases there are which are tied into the American military system or exactly what they do. There has been little debate about them in Parliament and, when the issue is raised by the Australian Democrats, by me, by Senator Dunn-and, I should add, when questions were asked by the Australian Labor Party when it was in opposition-or by the occasional member of the Liberal Party, there is a continuing wall of silence despite this Government's assertion that it is more open than its predecessors were about the bases.

As an exercise in testing the openness of the Labor Government, in 1986 I asked a question of the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, about the operations of the facility at Pine Gap. I copied the exact wording of a question that he had asked when he was in opposition of the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. Guess what answer I got? It was exactly the same answer that Prime Minister Fraser had given to Bill Hayden. The excuse given was `national security'. It is not our national security that is protected by such stupid answers but the national security of the United States.

If it was not for the courageous women who went to Pine Gap some years ago and other actions at North West Cape and Nurrungar, as well as those organised by the Australian anti-base campaign coalition and the Alice Springs peace group, even fewer Australians would know what was happening on their own soil. The active phase of ANZUS did not really begin until the United States intervention in Indo-China and the ill-fated decision to send Australian troops to Vietnam. It was a confusing period, because in 1966 the British Government announced that it would eventually withdraw its forces from the Far East and the Indian Ocean, and in 1969 President Nixon enunciated what became known as the Guam doctrine on a stop over there on his way back to the United States.

Proponents of self-reliance within the alliance often date the changes in Australian defence thinking to this time, because President Nixon spelt out in the Guam doctrine a fact which should have been understood right from the beginning of the signing of the ANZUS Treaty but which was never acknowledged by the Government, not in public anyway-that the United States does not intend to come to the rescue of any of its alliance partners, that alliance partners have to be prepared to defend themselves. Yet the myth has been perpetuated by government after government of either political complexion in Australia that because we are in ANZUS the United States would come to our rescue-and it is a lot of nonsense.

During these same years, up to 1972, conservative governments in Australia and New Zealand were prepared to pursue foreign policies which were often unpopular at home, such as continued support for the Vietnam war and refusing to recognise the People's Republic of China despite substantial trade ties. Not surprisingly, there was something of a backlash when Labor governments came to power in 1972 in Canberra and Wellington, but the dependency upon a great and powerful friend was deep and I doubt if we shall ever know how active the CIA was in destabilising the Whitlam Government before the coup in 1975. Suffice to say that it was this Government which first lifted the lid on three key United States bases that had been established during the Menzies years-first, North West Cape, then Pine Gap and Nurrungar. But even then we did not learn too much because on the famous occasion on 11 November 1975 when Gough Whitlam was ready to make a speech it was never made. Paradoxically, it was a coalition government under Billy McMahon which imposed a moratorium on the visit of nuclear-powered warships to Australian ports, which lasted from 1971 to 1976. At that stage there were, very surprisingly, no bleatings about our obligations under ANZUS to let these nuclear powered warships into our ports. That ban was lifted by the Fraser Government when Ian Sinclair was Minister for Defence in 1976.

Under this Government, there was a swing back to the special relationship with Washington as the arc of crisis developed in the north-west corner of the Indian Ocean, and United States warship visits peaked in the years after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. These were the years when an increasing number of United States warships were becoming nuclear-powered, when Malcolm Fraser allowed B52 bombers to stop off in Darwin and when he was prepared to offer the United States Navy the use of facilities at Cockburn sound if it needed a permanent home port there. Thankfully, it did not take up his offer. The offer was repeated later by John Howard when he was Leader of the Opposition.

Under the Hawke Labor Government, the claim of a special relationship was maintained, particularly in regard to the relationship between the Prime Minister and United States Secretary of State Shultz, their golf matches being renowned. There were frequent charges that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden, was not so popular, because at times he would speak his mind and assert a different line to the prevailing United States line on certain key issues. However, in the end, the Minister knew that he had to toe the line and that the prevailing myth of ANZUS had to stay intact. Australia worked hard for a comprehensive test ban treaty but was thwarted by opposition from the Reagan Administration and the lobby that wanted the United States to develop a third generation of nuclear weapons for the star wars program.

Bill Hayden raised the issue of naval arms control as well, but the United States Navy has adamantly refused to talk about that. That is one of the reasons why the United Nations General Assembly Third Special Session on Disarmament in New York last year was a flop. No agreement was signed at that meeting because the United States Government refused to allow the issue of naval arms control to be put on the agenda. Every time it was mentioned, the United States wiped out that paragraph; it was just not allowed by the United States. So the best disarmament efforts that have been put forward by this Australian Labor Party Government have been thwarted by our so-called great friend and ally. We have been stymied at every opportunity that we have taken. The United States, as a sea power, has always dominated the oceans while the Soviet Union, as a land power, put the emphasis on land-based missiles. Now the talks are under way on land-based missiles, the United States still refuses to discuss naval arms control. This issue is important for Australia, because it is the area that directly involves us through the symbolism of ANZUS.

There is a children's story about the emperor who had no clothes. I am sure that honourable senators are familiar with that story. Australia is rather like one of the people in the crowd who knew perfectly well that the emperor had no clothes but was too intimidated to say so. (Quorum formed) Only the child spoke in this case, the junior partner in ANZUS, that is, New Zealand. It dared to stand up to the emperor. I refer, of course, to the ludicrous `neither confirm nor deny' policy, when everyone knows that the United States Navy deploys nuclear weapons on 80 per cent of its warships but hardly anyone is prepared to challenge the `neither confirm nor deny' myth. It is curious that only small countries, the children in the legend, such as Belau, Iceland, Malta and New Zealand, are prepared to shout, `The emperor has no clothes'. Big countries such as Australia kowtow to the emperor, to the United States or to our colonial masters, the British. Australia is afraid to speak out-a mark of our subservience.

We are told that ANZUS allows us to have more influence with the United States. I think that is arrant nonsense. When a journalist from the Sydney Morning Herald came back from her post in Washington a few years ago, she said that the United States listened to what Australia had to say and then ignored us. The root problem is that after 200 years the non-Aboriginal people of Australia are deeply rooted in a cultural framework that is today based on three false assumptions: firstly, that we cannot defend ourselves; secondly, that we therefore need a great and powerful friend to protect us; and thirdly, that since 1942 the friend in question, the United States, has been a reliable ally.

As the Director of the Australian National University Peace Research Centre, Andrew Mack, observed in 1986, `the popular case for ANZUS does not have a great deal of currency in the Australian Government, where an altogether more sophisticated argument holds sway. This is the argument we refer to as the central balance. Mr Beazley then adds that under ANZUS we also get cheap, highly sophisticated, state-of-the-art technology which is necessary for the defence of Australia. He has christened his approach `self-reliance within the alliance'. This is a contradiction in terms. There is also the issue of shared intelligence but we are not allowed to know what that constitutes. All we do know is that we are a very junior partner in this intelligence arrangement with the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand. The UK-USA Agreement of 1947 is one of the most secret agreements in the world. At some later date I intend to speak about this issue of secrecy and intelligence because it is time it was challenged.

The problem in Australia is that few politicians have been willing to challenge these myths. I believe that with the rapid fading away of the Cold War, it is now time to challenge the myths of ANZUS and to seize the opportunity to declare Australian independence. For nearly 40 years we have been locked into an East-West view of the world when the reality for our part of the world is a concern for economic security or north-south issues. We have allowed hysteria about the Soviet Union and Libya and other alleged stalking horses to cloud our judgment. We have ignored the views of our South Pacific neighbours, who know that the Soviet Union has no great interest in this part of the world and poses neither a military nor an economic threat. In fact, it pays for the fish that the American Tuna Association plundered for years. Because of ANZUS we took on the American view of the world. Its enemies became our enemies. We say everything in terms of East-West issues that were entirely irrelevant in the South Pacific. We adopted its agenda as part of the cultural cringe. Our farmers saw that the so-called partnership was worth nothing when it came to bread and butter issues such as trade and protection but the cry went up from both major parties that we must not confuse economic issues and concerns about military security. Why not?

This brings me to the whole issue of alliance politics. A New Zealand academic, Jacob Berkovitch, edited a book of essays which has just come into the Parliamentary Library, entitled ANZUS in crisis: Alliance management in International Affairs. In it, he quotes a survey of post-war alliances, which identify 10 alliances involving two large powers, 86 involving a small state with large powers and 50 small states with other small states. It is patently obvious where Australia and New Zealand fit into this survey. Berkovitch comments that relations between a small state and a large one are inherently difficult. Small states seek security, yet resent being mere appendages of a great power. They want protection but do not wish to be unduly influenced. Apparently Machiavelli's advice to the prince of a small state was not to align himself with a more powerful state. I suspect this is about the only occasion on which I shall approvingly quote Machiavelli but I prefer his advice to that of King Bob of Australia because it is sound. It is humiliating to read about our delegations to the United States, which rank as headlines here, but do not even make the news in the United States. Every country goes there and few rank any mention in the United States media. Why do we persist in this ridiculous nonsense about our influence on and special relationship with the United States? We are spurned on bread and butter concerns, we get sent third-rate ambassadors, our representations are ignored, and yet we go on conning ourselves that we matter in Washington.

ANZUS is a symbol. It has allowed the United States to put bases on our soil with no community debate and rarely any parliamentary debate. We host the visits of nuclear warships, which only 28 per cent of Australians are now in favour of, yet are denied the chance to challenge this in the Parliament because of the bipartisan policy of the major parties, afraid to speak out after 200 years of subservience to great and powerful friends. When New Zealand rightly points out that there is nothing in the ANZUS treaty about nuclear warships it is frozen out of the club and Australia wimpishly concurs. This is an absolute disgrace. The ANZUS Treaty commits us to a yearly meeting-that is all-and a phone call in the event of a crisis; nothing else. The treaty fits on a single page. It is totally vague and deliberately so. All the secret agreements since 1951 have been drawn up in the spirit of ANZUS but there was never anything in the original treaty about them. How many honourable senators have read the text of the ANZUS treaty? One woman in Adelaide spent six weeks trying to get a copy from government departments because no-one had one. That is the essence of the myth because, in the end, few Australians really know what it is about but everyone pays lip service to it. As we count the cost of the Bicentennial in 1988 and move towards the real centenary of the Commonwealth of Australia in 2001 it seems that one appropriate reassessment might be the value of ANZUS.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health, following advice from State/Territory nurse registration authorities, State/Territory Health Departments, the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition and the Australian Nursing Assessment Council (ANAC), has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no countries with which Australia has reciprocity in respect of nursing qualifications. To be considered for registration as a nurse in Australia, a person must have qualified in a country with a health care system similar to that of Australia in terms of culture, technology, licensure and language. The following countries generally meet this requirement:

Canada, New Zealand, Republic of Ireland, South Africa, United Kingdom and the United States of America. In certain cases, a nurse who qualified elsewhere, but who has substantial experience as a fully registered nurse, or gained a post-basic qualification from one of the countries listed above, may be considered for registration.

(2) Registration of overseas trained nurses is a responsibility of individual State and Territory Governments. Any pre-registration bridging courses for overseas trained nurses deemed appropriate to meet Australian registration standards is also the responsibility of those Governments.

Courses have been conducted in South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania to meet a recognised demand. I understand that Western Australia has applied for Commonwealth funding to conduct a pilot course.
For those courses which are available, the requested information is as follows:
(a) Courses offered are all State pre-registration courses.
(b) There are no costs to applicants for courses offered.
(c) New South Wales-eight weeks. South Australia-fourteen weeks. Tasmania-twelve weeks full-time or twenty weeks part-time. Victoria-thirteen weeks minimum.

(d) College of Nursing, Glebe, New South Wales. College of Advanced Education, Bedford Park, South Australia. Tasmanian State Institute of Technology, Launceston, Tasmania. Austin Hospital, Box Hill Hospital, Western Metropolitan Regional Office, Victoria.

(e) Entry Requirements-New South Wales-NSW Nurses Registration Board assessment. South Australia-Assessed by ANAC and the Nursing Board of SA. Tasmania-Eligible for registration in Tasmania and basic competence in the English language. In the States/Territories where specific courses for overseas nurses are conducted, nurses are advised to contact the nurse registration authority in that State or Territory for advice concerning an appropriate course.

It is the officers in nurse registration authorities who render assistance to any nurse wishing to enter the workforce. Course co-ordinators are available to help advise nurses wishing to enter bridging programs or courses.

Over the last few years, Commonwealth monies have been available for retraining of nurses under the National Skills Shortage program, and have been available to assist States and Territories in providing programs to tap the pool of overseas trained nurses. The onus has been on the individual States/Territories to take up this offer. Recently, the Government announced strategies for reforming the recognition of overseas skills including overseas qualified nurses.

(4) The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Bowen, released on behalf of the Commonwealth on Friday 3 November, 1989, a policy statement outlining the Government's strategy for reforming migrant skills recognition. TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1989 Senator Sheil asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the decision to pay family allowances on a fortnightly basis instead of a monthly basis means that, in the first year of operation, families will be paid less than under the previous arrangement? Why has the Government refused to reveal findings of the Social Security Advisory Council's report on the matter? Can the Minister tell the women and children of Australia why the matter was referred to the Council in the first place if the Government has no intention of accepting its findings? Will the Minister now come clean and tell the Senate how much families are being short-changed by this decision?
The Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, has provided the following answer.
The Minister for Social Security has carefully considered the report of the SSAC's Working Party ``Report on the Effect of Family Payment Changes''.

However, the Minister does not endorse the Council's recommendations in this area. While the Minister accepts that there can be a variation in the amount of the final payment a given family may receive when the last of their children attracting family payments ceases to be eligible for them, it is difficult to accept the argument that ``losses'' have occurred or that such families should be compensated given prevailing standards of targeting areas of need and spending priorities.
The Council's major recommendation on adjustments rested on three principles:
legislative change should not reduce reasonable expectations about continuance of statutory entitlements unless clear notice is given before the legislation is changed;

in assessing the impact on families of the December 1988 change, the value of the July 1989 Family Allowance increases should be partially offset because of a decline in the value of Family Allowance since 1976-77 and that there was a likelihood that some of the decline would have been redressed in the short or medium term; and
increases in Family Allowance Supplement should be disregarded because that payment is for a different purpose than for Family Allowance.

The Minister accepts the first principle but does not accept that it is correct to speak of ``losses'' from one step in the rationalisation of family payments, especially when those ``losses'' have been more than compensated by other direct steps in that rationalisation process. Those ``losses'' the Council identified for some families would be wholly or substantially offset by including all related steps the Government has taken in the area of family assistance, such as the very substantial increases in Family Allowance rates, Child Disability Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement and additional pension and benefit rates in recent time.

It is also relevant to note that the Council's report does not make reference to the enhanced Common Allowance Structure now in place for student assistance which provides real gains for many of the affected families.

When the many related initiatives the Government has taken in the families area since the publication of the Social Security Review's Issues Paper No. 1 in October 1986 are taken into account, the Government's commitment to family assistance is clear. In the Family Allowance program alone those initiatives will add some $400 million (net) to outlays in 1989-90. It is disappointing that some have chosen to divorce one aspect of the many initiatives and raise concerns about it in isolation of all elements of the package. This is particularly so when the isolated issue in question is obviously a product of well forecast legislation and is totally in accordance with it.
The report proposed additional expenditure but avoided the issue of what savings measures would be necessary elsewhere in the portfolio to cover the additional expenditure.

In summary, the Minister has noted Council's view that the only potential area of losses occasioned by the change to fortnightly Family Allowance payments is in respect of families who lose their last child for family payment purposes within a relatively short time following December 1988. In the Minister's view, what are seen as losses are offset by other beneficial elements of the families package.
